title: Inscryption
description: From the creator of Pony Island and The Hex comes the latest mind-melting, self-destructing love letter to video games. Inscryption is an inky black card-based odyssey that blends the deckbuilding roguelike, escape-room style puzzles, and psychological horror into a blood-laced smoothie. Darker still are the secrets inscrybed upon the cards...

myData.review: I love this game. The only thing I knew before playing Inscryption was what I gathered from a 15 second clip from one of Dunkey's best games of the year videos; mainly that it was a card game with some escape room stuff thrown in and it gets crazy. So that's about all I'm going to tell you as well. I don't really feel like it's even worth talking about the graphics, music, controls, etc (which were all fine), because really for me it was about the whole experience of playing this. There are only a few games that have ever transcended the screen and messed with my head a little bit (Portal & Last of Us come to mind) to the point where it feels more like you're watching a movie or reading a book than playing a game. Inscryption may not be as strong a game as Portal or Last of Us, but I loved the experience through and through and will remember this game a lot longer than your average hack & slash or platformer.

title: ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights
description: Story: Long ago, in the distant reaches of Land's End... The unforeseen descent of the ""Rain"" transformed all living things into frenzied undead monstrosities known as the Blighted. Faced with a calamity far beyond their understanding with no recourse, the kingdom fell into ruin, with no end in sight to the accursed rain. Meanwhile, in the remnants of this ruined world, a young girl named Lily awakens in the depths of a church.
displayTitle: ENDER LILIES: Quietus of the Knights

myData.review: Yeah, this was a kinda cool metroidvania action game. You play as this kid and then some shadow guy that follows you around does the attacking. One thing I liked a lot was after you beat certain enemies, you can use one of their moves which makes it fun to customize your character and playstyle. I also liked the art and setting of the game. It's a bit on the difficult side, but don't think it got too crazy. I'm giving it a 3 cause even though I only played it like a year ago, I really don't remember very much, so even though I enjoyed it, the game didn't stick with me very much. But if you're looking for an indie metroidvania, this is one of the better ones.

title: Gris
description: Gris is a hopeful young girl lost in her own world, dealing with a painful experience in her life. Her journey through sorrow is manifested in her dress, which grants new abilities to better navigate her faded reality. As the story unfolds, Gris will grow emotionally and see her world in a different way, revealing new paths to explore using her new abilities.

myData.review: Gris is a beautiful moody 2D puzzle-y platformer game. The art is great, the music is great. It's fairly short, and it's not a particularly challenging game, but that's not really the point. Instead you play a series of moods which are expressed through color, music, and gameplay. It's definitely the most artistic game on the list, but I highly recommend it even if that's not really your thing. It goes on sale fairly often so pick it up for cheap and beat it in a weekend.

title: Super Mario RPG
description: Enter—or revisit—a world of whimsy with Mario on a quest to repair Star Road and defeat the troublemaking Smithy Gang. Team up with a party of unlikely allies, like the monstrous Bowser and a mysterious doll named Geno, in a story-rich RPG packed with laughs and quirky characters.

myData.review:
I've dreamed about the day of a new Mario RPG for the longest time. I've literally had dreams about it. This was the first RPG I've ever played. I remember renting it from Blockbusters one Friday having no clue what an 'RPG' was. I jumped on the first goomba I saw and was extremely confused and frustrated. But once I got past the initial learning curve, I was hooked. I remember specifically getting stuck on Bowyer, that arrow-slinging a-hole. Fast forward, a few months later, I bought this game from my elementary school friend Nathan, and got the players guide from Nintendo Power and just chugged Mario RPG for a couple weeks straight. I beat it over and over ago, and knew the game inside and out. There were always rumors of a second Mario RPG coming out one day... and then we got Paper Mario, and part of died. \n

Mario RPG is such a weird fun quirky game, the only game Nintendo (Mario) & Square (Final Fantasy) ever teamed up on. Not too soon after Mario RPG game out (it was late in the SNES lifecycle), Square abandoned Nintendo in favor of playstation, and the marriage was over. Anyways, let's talk about the game itself. It's a little of of a simplified RPG (but not totally in baby mode like Paper Mario) but Nintendo smartly throws this 'timed hits' system into the battle system to make the classic Final Fantasy RPG fight a little more active and engaging. The music is amazing (great fun themes). The characters and enemies are all diverse and rememberable. There's a big variety of minigames. And the story, though simple, is cute and compelling. You also get to team up with Bowser which is awesome. But my favorite part about the game is the large variety of secrets thrown into the game. There are hidden chests, bonus accessories and weapons, Link and Samus even make an appearance if you go to the right bed at the right time. One of my favorite little details is this random guy you can talk to behind a house. You can't see them and the conversation changes as you progress through the game if you go back to him. There's no reason or explanation to him, but he's there all the same. There are so many minor details added like this for no apparent reason. It's a very creative game that feels like it had a love of love that went into it. \n

Ok, onto the remake. I enjoyed playing through Mario RPG again, but the enhanced graphics didn't really add much to the experience. Though I will say, the enhanced graphics basically match how I remember the original game looking like. But it really didn't feel like there was enough meat here for this to justify the 60 dollar price tag. There is a tiny bit of post-game content (and I mean tiny) and a few other little niceties thrown in, but none of it is all that interesting or helpful. I may have well have played the original game honestly. So what would I have done differently? Well, if there was going to be any additional content, why not lean into that a little harder. Maybe a new level for instance? They could have used enemy sprites already in game just as a different color scheme. Maybe like a tournament arena type thing if not a whole new level? Just having the extra boss battles all in one area would have been nice too. The biggest easy win though honestly would have been having a New Game+ mode. I've never played a New Game+ but I would have for Mario RPG. End of rant. Mario RPG is a great game, if you've never played it. But if you have already played it, the remake doesn't add anything new.

title: XCOM 2 Collection
description: The XCOM® 2 Collection includes the award-winning strategy game XCOM 2, four DLC packs (Resistance Warrior Pack, Anarchy’s Children, Alien Hunters, Shen’s Last Gift) and the War of the Chosen expansion all in one package. Activate any of the additional content (DLCs and the Expansion) or just play the base game.

myData.review: I've said this about a few games on this list, but more than any of others, do not play XCOM 2 on the Switch. Overall I'm sure it's a bit slower and clunkier than a decent PC, but there are a few missions that are almost unplayable because of the lag. I'm pretty sure the game crashed once or twice as well. The other thing I'll say about XCOM is you probably shouldn't play with the expectation that all your characters are going to make it, or that you're going to succeed in completing the game on your first go through. There is a pretty steep learning curve here. You have to really strategize carefully to use your characters efficiently and effectively. With all that out of the way, it is a really fun and deep game if you like RPGs and strategy games. The meat of the game is a sci-fi tactical RPG, but there's also a Civilization-like component where you're conquering territories, collecting resources, building up your base. And then there are quests, and research, and tons of characters to maintain and keep track of an level up. And when a character dies, that's it, they're gone. You can get away with resetting the game and restarting the mission or loading from the last save, which I definitely did more than I should have if I was trying to preserve the spirit of the game. Anyways, XCOM was fun, fairly complicated, and requires some patience and attention. Play it if you like big mission driven tactical RPGs, but don't play it on the Switch.

title: Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night
description: Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night is a gothic horror action side-scrolling RPG set in 18th century England. A paranormal force has summoned a demon-infested castle, revealing crystal shards infused with tremendous magical power. Play as Miriam, an orphan scarred by an alchemist's curse which slowly crystallizes her body. To save humanity, and herself in the process, Miriam must fight through the castle and defeat the summoner, Gebel. Collect, craft and unlock a vast array of weapons, equipment and loot to defeat the countless minions and bosses of hell that await!

myData.review: This is marked as the spiritual successor of Castlevania, with some of the team that worked on those games. I think it does a good job of this? I've only actually ever played one Castlevania game - Aria of Sorrow, and it seems mostly in the same ballpark. I do very much appreciate the shear amount of abilities and play styles you can try out in this game. You can basically collect different abilities from enemies and then pick which ones you want to use, which is pretty sweet. The setting is cool, music is pretty good, graphics are kinda ehh - it's got some of that early 3D polygony look to it. I'm beating around the bush though, the big detractor here is the lag on the Switch. While not god-awful, it definitely takes away from the experience, so play it somewhere else. Overall, I did enjoy the game, but there are better ones in the same genre out there.

title: Super Mario 3D World + Bowser’s Fury
description: Pounce and climb through dozens of colorful courses! Multiply the fun by teaming up with or competing against friends locally or online to reach each stage’s goal. Work together to explore and uncover collectibles, or compete for the crown by earning the highest score, making for a friendly frenzy!

myData.review:
So for the record, as far as 3D games go, I think Mario Odyssey is a way better game than this if you were to just pick one as a solo gamer. Compared to Odyssey, this game feels boxy, and linear. The reason I'm giving this 5/5 stars is because of the multiplayer. There are so few non-FPS coop multiplayer games, especially in the 3D platforming world. It's fun, it's chaotic, it's silly, and has a good variety of levels (the captain toad puzzles levels for instance are a nice change of pace). It's also a fairly long game as far as Mario games go, and and has some pretty challenging moments towards the end. And yes, I know this game out on the Wii-U and it would not be my top pick as far as solo games go, even with the Bowsers Fury add-on. \n

Speaking of, let's talk about Bowsers Fury... It was alright. Honestly, I was pretty disappointed. On paper it sounds great, it takes the physics of Mario 3D world and turns it into one giant world with little islands acting more or less as levels. It's great not having the hard cut of a flag ceremony and menu screen in between levels, but as a result, I found Bowsers Fury all felt like pretty much the same level. As a whole, the whole experience was a little bland and mundane. It also suffered from the same blocky/boxyness of Mario 3D world. Still, it's Nintendo and I of course got all the Stars or Cat coins or whatever they're going with now. But yeah, Bowser's Fury, definitely not the *cats meow*
......is this thing on?

title: MARIO + RABBIDS SPARKS OF HOPE
description: Team up with Mario, Luigi, Princess Peach, Rabbid Peach, Rabbid Luigi, and their friends on a galactic journey to defeat a malevolent entity and save your Spark companions. Explore planets throughout the galaxy as you uncover mysterious secrets and compelling quests! Build your dream team with three heroes from an eclectic roster of nine. Take down all new bosses, along with some familiar enemies throughout the galaxy. Rescue the adorable Sparks throughout the galaxy, who provide distinct powers that will help you in battle. Unleash your heroes' skills but be strategic as you dash your enemies, team jump on your allies, and hide behind covers.

myData.review: I definitely applaud Sparks of Hope with taking the tactics-grid system and applying a more area based movement system to it. You still get more or less forced into a grid square, but it does feel more fluid and natural and is well done overall. The overworld is also more interesting than the first game. Each world you come across (island, artic, etc) has lots of explore and unlock, almost a bit like Mario Odyssey. It's not Mario Odyssey of course, but it still feels more open and less linear and boxy than the first Mario+Rabbids game. Beyond that, it's mostly the same game as the first with new levels. It has the same aesthetics (fun, colorful, silly, etc), and rpg elements (unlockable characters, skill-trees, etc) as the first game. The Rabbids also mostly annoyed me and I always played as the actual Mario characters if I could help it. But, like the first game, I did beat it, so I suppose that tells you something. (Though I did occasionally have to pull out the old eyeball bleach at times.)

title: Figment
description: A action-adventure set in the recesses of the human mind... Welcome to the world of Figment. A strange and surreal world; a place filled with our deepest thoughts, urges and memories, populated by the many voices we hear in our heads. This mind has been quiet and calm for many years. But something has changed. New thoughts have started to emerge - taking the shape of nightmarish creatures who spread fear wherever they go. The only hope is for the grumpy Dusty, the mind's former voice of courage, to get back to his old self and help the mind to face its fears.

myData.review: Sorry Figment, but I did not enjoy you. This was one of the first games I played on my Switch. I'm pretty sure I got it for super cheap. I know it's a short game, but it got off to a slow start and I didn't feel like the puzzles were very interesting and the world not too fun to explore. However, I'm looking at images now and it looks pretty cool... So I think I owe it another shot. I probably only played it like an hour maybe? I remember the main character kept yelling at this bird which kind of bothered me for some reason. Anyways, I think the art and music were good, but maybe not executed the best way? Take this all with a grain of salt. Maybe pick it up if you want a surreal puzzle game, but I would definitely get it on sale.

title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge
description: HEROES IN A HALF SHELL Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder’s Revenge features groundbreaking gameplay rooted in timeless classic brawling mechanics, brought to you by the beat ’em up experts at Dotemu (Streets of Rage 4) and Tribute Games. Bash your way through gorgeous pixel art environments and slay tons of hellacious enemies with your favorite Turtle, each with his own skills and moves - making each run unique!
displayTitle: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Shredder's Revenge

myData.review:
Shredder's Revenge was a fun multiplayer beat-em-up. But I felt it was a little disappointing. It doesn't quite capture the magic of the SNES classic Turtle in Time, though I think that's what they were going through. The levels weren't all that diverse or interesting, the collectables felt a little awkward and shoehorned in, and the game as a whole was on the short side. Still, it was fun to play through with friends. \n

The beat-em-up games in the Sega and SNES era weren't perfect, but they were fun because they were new and they looked great for their age. I feel that they've not really been able to bring that genre into the modern era very well, when it seems like it would be fairly easy to do. Castle Crashers might be the best post-2000s game I've seen do it. So how do I feel about Shredder's Revenge as a whole? it was alright for a bit. But overall underwhelming and disappointing. If you're looking for a short coop to play with friends, this might be up there on the list, but only because that's a pretty short list.

title: Legend of Mana
description: Set off on a journey to find the mystical Mana Tree seen in a dream, before discovering... the world map is empty! During your travels, you’ll acquire special artifacts; place these wherever you’d like on the map to bring towns and dungeons to life and advance the story. Meet a colorful cast of characters, square off against fearsome monsters, and complete quests in the vast world of Fa’Diel. Not only has the music been rearranged for this remaster, you can also alternate between the new and original soundtrack. Other features have also been added, including the ability to turn off enemy encounters, and the never-before released mini-game "Ring Ring Land".

myData.review: I love an action RPG, but I did not get super far into this game. I played Secret of Mana and Secret of Evermore as a kid and loved them both. Legend of Mana always looked awesome to me, but it just wasn't clicking. The combat felt a little clunky and then the overworld stuff was just kind of confusing and long winded. Maybe if I had more patience I could have enjoyed this more.

title: Balatro
description: The poker roguelike. Balatro is a hypnotically satisfying deckbuilder where you play illegal poker hands, discover game-changing jokers, and trigger adrenaline-pumping, outrageous combos.

myData.review: A fun, addicting game that somehow turns poker into a rougelike game. There are hundreds of these different jokers that you come across that can change your hand or the game in various ways. The endless combinations of jokers and hands keeps the game feeling fresh even after dozens of games in a row. That said, it's poker with a few enhancements. And as easily as I could sit there for hours hoping for that right combination of cards and jokers. I'd rather pull myself away and experience something new with a little more heart instead of just rolling the dice over and over.

title: Transistor
description: From the creators of Bastion, Transistor is a sci-fi themed action RPG that invites you to wield an extraordinary weapon of unknown origin as you fight through a stunning futuristic city. Transistor seamlessly integrates thoughtful strategic planning into a fast-paced action experience, melding responsive gameplay and rich atmospheric storytelling.

myData.review: It's the people who made Hades and Bastion, so Transistor's gotta be great, right? I uh.. Maybe it is? Honestly, I didn't get that far, maybe playing for like an hour or 2. But overall I found Transistor pretty confusing, and not super fun. It has a similar type of game play to Hades - the overhead action beat-em-up kinda thing, except that its cyberpunk-y and not a rougelike. That sounds great, except the combat and upgrade systems were not all that intuitive and the levels and maps were dark and opaque. Maybe there's just a bit of a learning curve or hump that I needed to get over, but I just did not find myself very engaged with Transistor but instead more confused and annoyed. Still, it's not like it was terrible, and maybe I'll give it another shot, but for now I'm left with a feeling of 'ehhh...'

title: Cat Quest II
description: Cat Quest is an open world RPG set in the pawsome world of cats! Leap into a grand adventure in purrsuit of the evil Drakoth and your catnapped sister! Explore Felingard's huge overworld map, risk life and limb delving into dungeons for epic loot, and lend a paw to a furry cast of characters in a flurry of side quests.

myData.review: I guess I knew what I was getting into with this game, having played the first one. But I thought they would have maybe expanded upon the original gameplay and theme a little bit. This is a simple action rpg with very little story, which is often what I want out of a game. But this one just ends up feeling a little too childish and simple. The humor is pretty dumb and the fighting gets repetitive pretty quickly without much changing in the way of skills or setting. I don't know, if you can pick it up for super cheap and want a game you can kind of zone out to, it kind of fits that mold. But yeah, this game is definitely not the cat's meow 😿

title: Super Mario Party
description: The original 4-player Mario Party series board game mode that fans love is back, and your friends and family are invited to the party! Freely walk the board: choose where to move, which Dice Block to roll, and how to win the most Stars in skill-based minigames. Wait till you see the 2 vs 2 mode with grid-based maps, the creative uses of the console, and the series’ first online minigame mode! Test your skills in sets of five minigames with the new mode, Mariothon, and see how you stack up against players across the globe in Online Mariothon.

myData.review:
This is the only Mario Party game I've ever actually owned. I've never been a big Mario Party person, but it's fun to play in a casual setting with friends. I don't think this is the cream of the crop as far as Mario Party games go. The overworld is needlessly confusing. It kind of feels like there are too many coins compared to stars. I don't think I was ever limited to buy a star by the number of coins. One new mode I did like was when the levels opened it up so you could play on a grid instead of a path. This was a cool new addition. The only problem was if you wanted to land on a certain space, you often needed to roll either an even or odd number, even if you got near the space long before the other team. \n
But yeah, I had fun with the game for a bit, and I'd always be willing to put it out if I had people over who wanted to play. That said, I think there are better multiplayer games, including other Mario Party games.

title: Hades
description: BATTLE OUT OF HELL As the immortal Prince of the Underworld, you'll wield the powers and mythic weapons of Olympus to break free from the clutches of the god of the dead himself, while growing stronger and unraveling more of the story with each unique escape attempt. UNLEASH THE FURY OF OLYMPUS The Olympians have your back! Meet Zeus, Athena, Poseidon, and many more, and choose from their dozens of powerful Boons that enhance your abilities. There are thousands of viable character builds to discover as you go. BEFRIEND GODS, GHOSTS, AND MONSTERS A fully-voiced cast of colorful, larger-than-life characters is waiting to meet you! Grow your relationships with them, and experience thousands of unique story events as you learn about what's really at stake for this big, dysfunctional family. BUILT FOR REPLAYABILITY

myData.review: Hades is just a fun game. It's a roguelike at heart, but the combat is just super tight, and the different combinations of weapons available and blessings randomized throughout a run keep the game endlessly interesting. Music, and graphics are good, artstyle and lore are really cool. And there is just an insane amount of really well done voice acting and dialogues which never really got old for me. So yeah, super fun game, but at the end of the day, it is really is just 4 levels repeated endlessly.

title: Borderlands Collection
description: Get three times the mayhem, three times the loot, and three times the action with the Borderlands Legendary Collection! Kill bandits and beasts, collect powerful weaponry, and maybe even save the universe in Borderlands: Game of the Year Edition, Borderlands 2, and Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, along with piles of bonus add-on content for each game, adding 100+ hours of gameplay at an incredible value. Enjoy all three games solo or cooperatively with local two-player split-screen or four-player online play.

myData.review: I don't really know how to review these collection games, but honestly they all kind of blend together anyways. I did have a great time playing through them all with friends, but mostly because it was with friends. The online experience worked pretty well and the games are well suited for the co-op experience. But as far as the franchise itself, I'm not actually a huge fan. The art-style is meh, the humor is stupid, the story is whatever, and the missions are all pretty generic. There's also just way too much gear that is mostly all kind of the same. And the rare items are way too rare to the point where you barely ever find any - and if you do they might not work for your character, and they'll be obsolete in a level or two anyways. So yeah, it's fun as a co-op game, but as far as other post-apocalyptic first person shooter/rpgs (*cough* fallout), this doesn't even come close.

title: Ring Fit Adventure
description: Traverse grass-swept plains by jogging in place, attack enemies with overhead shoulder presses, and refill your health meter by striking some yoga poses. Two new accessories, the Ring-Con™ and Leg Strap, measure your real-world actions and help turn them into in-game movements. With additional minigames and customizable workout routines, Ring Fit Adventure is great escape for players of all skill levels and schedules.

myData.review: So for a regular old game, this is nothing special. But for a fitness game, Ring Fit is great. The ring itself is a little awkward to use, but you mostly get used to it. Unfortunately with apartment living I've not been able to play this as much as I would like. FYI make sure you have decently high ceilings and some space around you when playing. Again, for a fitness game it's pretty fun. It's basically an RPG where you fight goofy enemies like dumbbells and kettlebells with some minigames thrown in there. It's not amazing, but it's fun while you're exercising.

title: Guacamelee! 2
description: Luchador Juan Aguacate is out of retirement for a stunning new Metroidvania-style adventure. Explore a huge, hand-crafted world inspired by Mexican culture and folklore, filled with sassy new villains and weirdos (and a few old friends!). Learn bone-crunching wrestling moves to fend off skeletal hordes and overcome skillful platforming challenges... and who said anything about a Chicken Illuminati? Certainly not us! Check out these features: Drop-in 4-player local co-op for you and your best amigos! New upgrade system: discover “trainers” around the world to learn new skill sets for movement, combat, and more! All new areas. Explore from the Mangrove Swamp to Hell itself! Double the enemy types of the original, and a roster of eccentric new bosses! Electro-Mexican soundtrack, and more gorgeous visuals thanks to a fancy new rendering engine! Definitely no secret society of chickens that teaches you ancient chicken abilities!

myData.review: I didn't play the first Guacamelee, so maybe I'm missing out on a little bit of character development and lore here. I always was a little put off by how dumb I thought the name of this game was. But as I played through Guacamelee I did come to appreciate the celebration of Mexican culture - particularly lucha libres and Dia De Los Muertos. However, I thought the graphics, music and gameplay were just alright. The best part for me was trying to string together different moves to get your combo score as high as possible. There are a few challenging sections thrown in if you're going for the completionist factor. But yeah, as a whole, it was a fun solid Metroidvania, but nothing above and beyond.

title: Pikmin 4
description: Guide pint-sized creatures in an endearing expedition! Meet Pikmin: small, plantlike creatures with distinct abilities that you can grow, pluck, guide, and overpower enemies with! Use your Pikmin’s miniature might (and a bit of strategy) to explore this mysterious planet in search of your crew—and treasure.

myData.review: Ok, disclaimer -- I only played the demo. I never really got Pikmin. I guess I didn't really get the point or what was fun about it. But I will say, I liked this game a lot more than I thought I would. It took a little bit to get going but I really enjoyed exploring the levels and collecting the random objects throughout. It kind of mixes a few different genres of games: city builder, puzzle, collectathon into a pretty interesting experience. So, I did enjoy it, but not enough to buy it. Who knows, maybe I'll be back.

title: Into the Breach
description: The remnants of human civilization are threatened by gigantic creatures breeding beneath the earth. You must control powerful mechs from the future to hold off this alien threat. Each attempt to save the world presents a new randomly generated challenge in this turn-based strategy game from the makers of FTL. Features: Defend the Cities: Civilian buildings power your mechs. Defend them from the Vek and watch your fire! Perfect Your Strategy: All enemy attacks are telegraphed in minimalistic, turn-based combat. Analyze your opponent's attack and come up with the perfect counter every turn. Build the Ultimate Mech: Find powerful new weapons and unique pilots as you battle the Vek infestation across Corporate-Nation islands. Another Chance: Failure is not an option. When you are defeated, send help back through time to save another timeline!

myData.review: Into the Breach is such a well made game. I love how clean and simple the levels are, yet they require complex strategies to beat. It's a tactics game in the most purest of forms - existing somewhere on the line between Final Fantasy Tactics and Chess. You're often working with units that have like 2 health and deal 1 damage. But some attacks have things like knockback which can add more damage, so you're constantly having to do more with less and really think through each turn. The game also has some roguelike features. As you beat each series of levels you can unlock different starter units, each with their own abilities. Definitely pick this one up, it's great!

title: Streets of Rage 4
description: Amongst the best beat’em up series ever created, jammin’ ‘90s beats and over the top street beating, the iconic series Streets of Rage comes back with a masterful tribute to and revitalization of the classic action fans adore.

myData.review: I didn't get super far in this game, but it was fun for a bit. I'm sure it would have been more fun with other people so I'd be interested in picking it up again with another player. It feels pretty similar to the original Streets of Rage games for Sega so they did a good job there. But like I said, I didn't get super far, but seems to play well as a classic arcade beat-em-up.

title: Aggelos
description: Step through time and discover a mesmerizing new action-RPG that looks like it was plucked straight out of the 16-bit era, but plays like a modern-day marvel! Inspired by non-linear Japanese retro adventures, Aggelos hurls players into the middle of a colossal struggle for survival as beings from another dimension threaten to invade the peaceful Kingdom of Lumen. Bursting with secrets and side-quests, and boasting slick melee combat that any 2D action game would envy, Aggelos is the perfect combination of retro style and modern-day game design.

myData.review: A kind of fun fairly short throwback adventure.  If you're aching for an indie metroidvania platformer and can pick it up for cheap, might be worth playing.  Nothing too memorable here but no giant take-aways either.

title: Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze
description: Barrel-blast into a critically acclaimed Donkey Kong adventure as this beloved franchise makes its Nintendo Switch™ debut with a banana-bunch of new features. Traverse islands packed with platforming perfection and nonstop action as the classic Kongs in the original game, or mix things up by playing the story as Funky Kong in new Funky Mode! Arctic invaders have turned Donkey Kong Island into their personal frozen fortress, and it’s up to you to save the day. Play as Donkey Kong in Original Mode and team up with Diddy Kong, Dixie Kong, and Cranky Kong—each with unique abilities—to overcome platforming challenges and frosty foes.

myData.review:
If you're looking for 2D modern platformers for the Switch, this is definitely one of the better ones. I'd say it's slightly better than the first Donkey Kong Country Returns. You don't have the blow mechanic anymore (thank god!) and it's just more polished and exciting overall. The levels are often very engaging and interactive, whether you're being chased in a mine cart or making your way through a fruit factory. As was the case with the first DKCR, this game is pretty hard through and through. It doesn't just save the tough levels for the very end like Mario does. I think it was the second secret level I found, "Bopopolis", where I easily died over 100 times before beating it. (Maybe wine and dine me a bit first, good lord...) But overall I enjoyed the challenge since 100%ing this game is tough, but not impossible.

Now, let's get real here for a moment. Yes, this is a good game, but no it's not as good as the original Donkey Kong Country games. I feel like your movement is really restricted with both the new DKCR games. Why does my jump feel so low? I really enjoyed the freedom of movement in the original DKC games. Plus, the atmosphere and vibes just feel off to me with the Return games. Everything's just a little too pretty and just-so. The original DKC game had this warm organic feel with amazing atmospheric music that you just don't get with Tropical Freeze. And why the heck is Cranky all happy now? Is he on pills or something? Also, I didn't mention, but yes, there are 4 different characters you can play as in Tropical Freeze and they all play slightly different. Now if only they played a little more like the original Diddy and Dixie...

title: Sonic Mania
description: Experience the ultimate celebration of past and future in Sonic Mania, an all-new 2D Sonic adventure running at a crisp 60FPS with stunning HD retro-style graphics. Multiple playable characters give you the ability to go explosively fast as Sonic, soar as Tails, or power through tough obstacles with Knuckles’ brute strength. You can re-live the Sonic of the past with an exciting new twist on classic zones while fighting against new bosses and Dr. Eggman’s evil robot army. Go head to-head with players in Competition Mode or play in Co-Op Mode with a friend. Sonic Mania was developed by Christian Whitehead, Headcannon, and PagodaWest Games in collaboration with Sonic Team. Welcome to Sonic Mania!

myData.review:
I've waited so long for this game -- a brand new Sonic game completely the style of the original Sonic games... It looks, sounds, and feels just like you're playing one of the Genesis games (matching most directly to Sonic 3). Most of the level themes are borrowed from one of the original games (even Sonic CD), though there are a handful of new ones as well. \n

Ok, background... I got a Sega Genesis for my birthday in 1st grade with one game... Sonic the Hedgehog. The next year I got Sonic 2 for my birthday, and Sonic 3 the following year. Those were the only games I had for years.  I've beat them dozens of times at different points in my life (Sonic & Knuckles and Sonic CD came a little later for me). Anyways, I think I've earned my Sonic stripes and am qualified to criticize Sonic Mania a bit... \n

First off, I liked Sonic Mania a lot. I beat it with all the different characters, beat all the bonus stages, blah blah blah, 100% completion. I didn't loooove Sonic Mania all the way through though. I'm a big fan of the original Sonic the Hedgehog which is a slower paced, more explorey type game compared to the later ones. The old Sonic games were always great because you could get familiar with each level, but still find new paths and secrets later one. Sonic Mania levels were so vast though it was hard to ever get any sort of familiarity. Looking for emeralds and trying to backtrack and explore can be kind of frustrating when each level is a winding maze set up for you to sprint through. The next is a personal gripe that most of the level themes they chose to imitate were not my favorite stages - I know that's personal, so I'll let it slide. There were a couple new playable characters which was cool, but I kind of wish they took a little liberty to go farther in terms of experimenting  with mechanics. One thing I would have loved to see are more item boxes. Sonic 3 may not have been as strong a game as 1 or 2 level-wise, but the bubble, fire, and lightening shields you can get are a super fun addition. I think they really missed the chance to explore that mechanic. Extra shields? Shield combos? Backup shields? Vegetable shield? I think that's enough on Sonic Mania. I still have like 20 games to review...

title: Fire Emblem™: Three Houses
description: War is coming to the continent of Fódlan. Here, order is maintained by the Church of Seiros, which hosts the prestigious Officer’s Academy within its headquarters. You are invited to teach one of its three mighty houses, each comprised of students brimming with personality and represented by a royal from one of three territories. As their professor, you must lead your students in their academic lives and in turn-based, tactical RPG battles wrought with strategic, new twists to overcome. Which house, and which path, will you choose?

title: Yoshi’s Crafted World
description: Jump into a new Yoshi adventure in a world made of everyday objects—like boxes and paper cups! As Yoshi, you’ll leap up high, gulp down enemies, and set out on a treasure hunt to find all the different collectables. On the flip side, stages can be played backwards, providing new perspectives to explore and new ways to locate some of the more craftily hidden items!

myData.review:
I liked Yoshi's Crafted World, but not that much, which made it the perfect game to play before bed. It has a very charming, creative aesthetic that I didn't quite 'get', but they really take it and run with it to the maximum effect. The levels go for this cardboard, DIY crafted thing, kind of in the realm of a school play. Each time you beat a level, you could play the same level in reverse; not just backwards, but like actually reverse. Imagine if the camera rotates 180° into the screen and now you're on the backside of the level, revealing what's been behind trees and other random level obstacles. These extra levels usually involved searching for certain items, kind of like playing eye-spy. This did get a little old for me, but it was still a really cool part of the game. \n

So I liked this game probably more than most people that are over the age of 12 would. It was clever and fun, but the baby-ish aesthetic did ware on me. Also, it felt like there was only like one song in the entire game. There were variations of it, sure, but yeah - that really got old. I'm honestly not sure there was a second song. So yeah, a game that had some really well done parts that was made for same target audience of Ms. Rachel.

title: SteamWorld Quest: Hand of Gilgamech
description: SteamWorld Quest is the roleplaying card game you’ve been waiting for! Lead a party of aspiring heroes through a beautifully hand-drawn world and intense battles using only your wits and a handful of cards. Take on whatever threat comes your way by crafting your own deck choosing from over 100 unique punch-cards! What awaits you is a luscious treasure chest filled with gold, dragons, vivid worlds, magic, knights in shining armor as well as XP, turn-based battles and all that good RPG stuff! The game’s humorous mix of traditional fantasy and steampunk robots makes for an unforgettable experience with lots of laughs.

myData.review: Another pretty good SteamWorld game. This one's an RPG where the character's moves are determined by cards. It's a good idea in theory, but just so-so in execution. You could upgrade your cards and swap out cards for others, but I guess it didn't feel as flushed out as it could have been. The combat and enemies were decent but the levels themselves felt pretty flat. Each area was segmented into a little rectangle that made exploration pretty minimal. I played through the whole game and it was fun, but nothing too special overall.

title: DOOM (1993)
description: Celebrate DOOM’s 25th anniversary with the re-release of the original DOOM (1993). First released in 1993, DOOM introduced millions of gamers to the fast-paced, white-knuckle, demon-slaying action the franchise is known for. Experience the classic demon-blasting fun that popularized the genre home or on-the-go. DOOM (1993) includes: - The expansion, Episode IV: Thy Flesh Consumed, with 9 additional action-packed levels - Local 4 player deathmatch - Local 4 player co-op

myData.review: Really... 5 for the original Doom? Come on... Ok yes, I know that's a bit absurd to give a 30+ year old game a 5/5 rating on Switch. But in my defense I only gave it a 5 because it wouldn't let me enter in a 6. TBH I was surprised how much I enjoyed playing through the original Doom again. And then I went on and played through several of the add-ons. There are soooooo many levels. And they get haaaaard. I definitely abused the save/load feature 🤷🏻‍♀️. There's something extremely satisfying about killing old school demons with a double barrel shotgun. I just love the sounds in this game too - the deaths, the gun shots, even the doors opening/closing. I could go on... this is one of the best game and well made games of all time. While playing through newer games on this list, I found myself thinking - 'yeah, this is pretty good, but look at what Doom was doing 30 years ago!'. I know it's a tough comparison but its good to have some standards - A north star to help guide us and remind us to RIP AND TEAR!

title: Tetris 99
description: The Tetris® 99 digital game includes an online mode that is a special offer for Nintendo Switch Online members*. In large-scale, 99-player battles, it’ll take speed, skill, and strategy to knock out the competition and become the last player standing. You can target opponents by sending them Garbage Blocks, but be careful… Your rivals can target you back! Defeat opponents to acquire K.O. Badges that may give you the advantage on future attacks. Nintendo Switch Online members can also look forward to upcoming online events*!

myData.review: I only played this a few times. I didn't ever win. I think I did ok. But it's a free game you can get on the Switch that doesn't really try to sell you anything. Maybe I need to get better at Tetris, but unless you're pretty dang good, I doubt you'll be playing this more than a handful of times.

title: Hyrule Warriors: Age of Calamity
description: Join the struggle that brought Hyrule to its knees. Learn more about Zelda, the four Champions, the King of Hyrule and more through dramatic cutscenes as they try to save the kingdom from Calamity. The Hyrule Warriors: Age of Calamity game is the only way to see firsthand what happened 100 years ago. - Battle hordes of Hyrule’s most formidable foes - From barbaric Bokoblins to towering Lynels, menacing monsters have emerged in droves. In addition to Link and Zelda, take control of characters like the four Champions and a young Impa. Use their distinct abilities to carve through hundreds of enemies to save Hyrule from the impending Calamity. If you have save data for the Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild game, you can get the in-game Training Sword bonus item. Equip this weapon and you’ll automatically hold a Pot Lid as a shield. This combo may also trigger the occasional Perfect Guard!

myData.review: So this is basically Dynasty Warriors with Zelda skins. I was only barely aware of what Dynasty Warriors was before diving into this, but in my head, it involved strategy and tactics and capturing bases... that kinda thing. Instead the only "strategy" I ever used was to press "A" over and over again. There are bosses and different playable characters and that kinda thing, but it's all kind of the same. It's a dumb game where you just zone out kill enemy after enemy. Don't get me wrong, I played through the whole thing... but you kinda get the idea after one level of this.

title: Yooka-Laylee and the Impossible Lair
description: They must run, jump and roll their way through a series of challenging 2D levels, face a puzzling Overworld and rally the Royal Bee-tallion to take down Capital B and his Impossible Lair! Each level offers beautiful, rich visuals with detail and depth. Yooka, Laylee and a whole host of colourful characters (good and bad) are realised in stunning 2.5D The overworld isn’t just a hub to hop from level to level, it provides a whole separate gaming experience!

myData.review: Yooka-Laylee was one of the first games I played on the Switch and it was prettttty good. Solid B. I particularly liked the world map. You can explore it, interact with things, there are secrets, etc. It's like somewhere in between the Mario 3 and Banjo Kazooie overworld map. But anyways, let's get into the actual game. It's a 2D platformer, pretty similar in style to Donkey Kong Tropical Freeze. And its prettttttttttty good. As you can maybe tell from the amount of 't's I'm puttttting in words, I liked the game, but I didn't love the game. Which is a little disappointing because I love Banjo Kazooie, and I love 2D classic platformers. I think the levels themselves were just a bit hit or miss. They had some fun, inspired moments, but also a lot of mediocre ones as well. The controls just always felt a little stiff as well. But it's been a few years and I'm having trouble remembering specifics. I enjoyed Yooka Laylee, but I was also ready for it to be over when it was.

title: New Pokémon Snap
description: Explore lush scenery on unknown islands to snap photos of Pokémon in their natural habitats Seek out and take in-game photographs of Pokémon in their native environments in the New Pokémon Snap™ game, only for the Nintendo Switch™ system! Snap photos from the NEO-ONE as you you encounter and research lively wild Pokémon. You might see unexpected expressions or behaviors—Pokémon patrolling their territory, playing, or lurking in out-of-the-way spots. Investigate the mysterious Illumina phenomenon. Travel to the islands that make up the Lental region. In this region, some of the Pokémon and vegetation will appear to have a special glow. Research these Pokémon alongside Professor Mirror as you explore dense jungles, vast deserts, and more! Your observations of Pokémon thriving in the wild may help unravel the truth behind the Illumina phenomenon.

myData.review: So, I love Pokemon Snap. It's such a dumb, fun, silly game. And the new one was fun too. Of course it ended up being the same rail mechanics of original game, where you ride around on a set course chucking apples and playing the poke-flute over and over (Man, does that song get old). But it still has a certain charm and lack of pretension which I really appreciate. Of course the dream of Pokemon Snap, and really all Pokemon games is to be able to walk around in an open world with the pokemon just out and about. One might think that 25 years after the original Pokemon Snap game came out, they'd be able to do that by now. If in another 25 years a new Pokemon Snap with the same rail mechanics comes out again, I will be so disappointed, but I'll probably still buy it.

title: Dex
description: You play as the mysterious blue-haired girl named Dex who is being hunted by a powerful and enigmatic organization for her unique abilities. Explore the misty, futuristic streets of Harbor Prime in this open-world dystopia. Unearth plots and intrigues, forge alliances and take the fight to your enemies on your quest to take down the system! The world of Dex is designed as a tribute to some of the greatest neo-noir and cyberpunk worlds with a mature storyline, murky atmosphere and distinct characters.

myData.review: This game was alright. It's kinda like 2D cyberpunk noir RPG maybe? It just doesn't feel that well polished. I did appreciate the different ways of tackling missions (kind of Fallout-esque) and the setting. But the whole thing just feels a little... not super well made? I'm not quite sure what could be improved besides everything maybe? Boy I'm really bashing this game. I didn't hate it. I played all the way through and kind of enjoyed it. The story was fine. The controls and combat just felt a little imprecise. So, play it if you want, or don't. Yeah, probably don't.

title: Worms W.M.D
description: The Worms are back in their most destructive game yet. With a gorgeous, hand-drawn 2D look, a full arsenal of weapons, crafting, vehicles and buildings, Worms W.M.D is the best Worms experience ever! In Worms W.M.D for Nintendo Switch™, players will be able to feel the full power of all the game’s campaign missions, levels, customisations and updates, including Liberation and the fan favourite Forts Mode whether at home or on the go.

myData.review: I used to play Worms 2 at my friend's house growing up and I remember it as one of the best multiplayer gaming experiences I ever had. Worms Armageddon came along, and I enjoyed that as well. Years later, out comes WMD... and it was fine? Games like this always make me wonder if I'm fantasizing about the past with nostalgia colored glasses, or if the newer version just isn't as good. I'd venture to say in this case, some of both. Certainly the novelty of being young and playing violent ridiculous games like this for the first time was a big part of the appeal. But Worms WMD doesn't offer anything new that's particularly exciting or interesting either. It's really just the same Worms 2/Worms Armageddon game again, this time with some vehicles thrown in. And the vehicles feel pretty clunky and awkward to use. It's disappointing they haven't found a way to improve the basic games slow pacing and sluggish movement. I played it a few times with friends and had fun, but there just really wasn't enough there to make it worth many replays or exploring the single player missions.

title: Metroid Dread
description: Join bounty hunter Samus Aran as she tries to escape a deadly alien world in the critically-acclaimed Metroid Dread. Upon investigating a mysterious transmission on Planet ZDR, Samus faces a mysterious foe that traps her in this dangerous world. The remote planet has been overrun by vicious alien lifeforms and murderous robots called E.M.M.I. Hunt or be hunted as you make your way through a labyrinth of enemies in Samus’ most intense side-scrolling adventure yet.

myData.review: Metroid Dread is possibly the most disappointing game I played on the Switch. Not because it was terrible, it was overall pretty decent, but because I had high expectations for it. After playing Nintendo games like Breath of the Wild and Mario Odyssey, Metroid Dread feels a bit like an afterthought. It plays very well, and looks & sounds pretty good good, but doesn't at all go beyond the original 2D Metroid games. The new mechanics - mostly these robots that kill you instantly if you get to close to them are frustrating to deal with. You will die a lot dealing with these guys. I think Dunkey put it well when he said Metroid Dread is simultaneously too confusing while being too linear. Whenever you get a new ability, it's not at all obvious where you're supposed to go, so you have to search the whole map to find that one place you now have access to. Overall, I would still recommend it if you like the Metroid series, though you may get more enjoyment just going back and playing Metroid for the SNES.

title: Metal Slug Tactics
description: METAL SLUG is back with a brand new entry in the METAL SLUG universe. Discover a new side of the emblematic run'n'gun and jump into a dynamic tactical RPG with roguelike elements! Super fun and lighthearted, Metal Slug Tactics takes what makes METAL SLUG so special and unique and brings it to the tactical genre!

myData.review: Oof, almost unplayable. The lag was a lot... I would do an action and the sound of a gunshot would happen like 2 seconds later. I know it's called Metal SLUG, but come on... This game also had the problem of shoving way too much info in your face right off the bat. The info was overwhelming, navigating through the controls was confusing, the characters all kind of seemed the same... and yeah, it lagged a lot right off the bat. Maaaaaaaybe if they work out the kinks in an update I'll revisit this, but this game has some serious stink on it, so probably not.

title: LIMBO
description: Uncertain of his sister's fate, a boy enters LIMBO LIMBO is an award-winning indie adventure, critically acclaimed for its captivating puzzle design and immersive sound and visuals. Its dark, misty spaces and haunting narrative will stay with you forever. Winner of more than 100 awards, including: Gameinformer’s “Best Downloadable” Gamespot’s “Best Puzzle Game” Kotaku’s “The Best Indie Game” GameReactor’s “Digital Game of the Year” Spike TV’s “Best Independent Game” X-Play’s “Best Downloadable Game” IGN’s “Best Horror Game”

myData.review: LIMBO was a lot darker and creepier than I thought it would be - in a good way. It's a bit of a platformer/puzzle game all in black and white. The creatures and accompanying soundscape all make for a kind of eerie, unsettling experience - again in a good way. It's definitely on the shorter side, but often goes on sale I think for like 2 bucks. All in all it's a nice little indie game with a horror inspired theme.

title: Owlboy
description: Owlboy is a story-driven platform adventure game, where you can fly and explore a brand new world in the clouds! Pick up your friends, and bring them with you as you explore the open skies. Overcome obstacles and greater enemies, in one of the most detailed adventures of this era. Being a mute, Otus struggles living up to the expectations of owl-hood. Things spiral from bad to worse with the sudden appearance of sky pirates. What follows is a journey through monster infested ruins, with unexpected encounters, well kept secrets, and burdens no one should have to bear. • A love letter to pixel art for a new audience, Owlboy is a story-driven action adventure, with a unique mix of flight and platforming. • Carry anything. Recruit Otus’s friends as gunners to fight for you, each with unique abilities and stories. • Large dungeons with big and challenging boss battles. • An adventure 10 years in the making.

myData.review: Owlboy plays well on the Switch. It doesn't lag, or have frame rate drops, or crash. And crazy enough, that's a big plus compared to a lot of games on the Switch. Unfortunately, that's probably the best part about Owlboy. On paper, it seems like this should be a pretty good game, but I just never found it very enjoyable. The story is generic, the levels are boring, the characters and dialogues are annoying. Graphics and music are decent, and you can fly everywhere which is kind of cool. But playing Owlboy always felt like a chore. I can't put my finger on exactly what was missing here. It's kind of a cute little adventure game, but I just did not find it very enjoyable. 2 out of 5 hoots.

title: Child of Light: Ultimate Edition
description: Join Aurora on her journey to save her ailing father and a lost kingdom in the magical world of Lemuria –along the way she'll discover that her destiny may be far greater than she dreamed. From award-winners Patrick Plourde and Jeffrey Yohalem comes Child of Light®. Encounter eccentric creatures, from wicked witches to evil sea serpents, and discover the vast land of Lemuria. Fight alongside your allies to upgrade your stats, unlock unique abilities, and use unique gems to improve your skills. Work together with your allies to solve puzzles and search for mysteries. Experience a story carefully crafted in verse and rhyme with an original soundtrack by composer Coeur de pirate.

myData.review: Oh man... another game that should not be played on the Switch. I really liked this game! It's beautiful, it has a great atmosphere. All the character's talk in rhyme except for one sad clown who just can't ever seem to make it work. There was an interesting timing mechanic with the RPG battle system that I liked a lot. But man oh man, this game was choppy as hell on the Switch. Can frame rates be negative? If you want a light hearted whimsical adventure/rpg you should definitely play this -- just don't play it on the Switch.

title: Kirby and the Forgotten Land
description: Float off on an all-new adventure as the powerful puffball, Kirby. Explore in 3D stages as you discover a mysterious world with abandoned structures from a past civilization—like a shopping mall?! Copy enemies’ abilities like the new Drill and Ranger and use them to attack, explore your surroundings, and save the kidnapped Waddle Dees from the ferocious Beast Pack alongside the mysterious Elfilin. Hope you’re hungry for an unforgettable adventure! Get a mouthful of real-world objects for all-new, powerful transformations.

myData.review: Kirby and the Forgotten Land is the second best 3D platformer that I've played, after Mario Odyssey. And to be fair, it's not nearly as good as Mario Odyssey. But it's still really good! It's just a fun game. The levels are bright and colorful and I love exploring each ability and trying to get good with each of them. There's a hub world with some minigames; those were all ok. You can also level up Kirby's abilities which was satisfying, but I had kinda mixed feelings about. Level's are fairly linear with some hidden stuff along the way. One unexpected area this game really excelled at is the boss battles. They are epic, and actually get pretty hard at the end. It's not a super long game, but if you can get it on sale, I definitely recommend it.

title: Lil Gator Game
description: The island is your playground. There’s a buddy atop every hill in this open-world, movement-focused adventure and they all seem to need help! Bop cardboard baddies, brave serene hills and forests, and scale sheer rocks that only a kid would dare!

myData.review: Oh man, I really liked this game. It's small, a little juvenile, and feels a little out of the box play-wise. But Lil Gator Game punches way above it's weight in terms of being a fun, complete adventure game. I really enjoyed the movement of the main character, and just how fast you can sprint around the world. You find all sorts of NPC characters throughout the world, each of which is a different animal. There are quests and abilities to unlock, almost like a mini-zelda game. It's also setup from the perspective of a DIY, pretend adventure game - all the enemies are cardboard for instance. It is a short game as I mentioned above, but it's a super fun game to 100% complete. Also, the story and dialogues are very charming and cute.

title: QUAKE
description: Developed by the award-winning id Software, Quake® is the ground-breaking, original dark fantasy first-person shooter that inspires today’s retro-style FPS games. Now, experience the authentic, updated, and visually enhanced version of the original. Experience the Original Game, Enhanced Enjoy the original, authentic version of Quake, now with HD* and widescreen resolution support, enhanced models, dynamic and colored lighting, anti-aliasing, depth of field, the original, atmospheric soundtrack and theme song by Trent Reznor, and more. There’s never been a better time to play Quake.

myData.review: This was my first time playing Quake, and it's a pretty fun game to play co-op with a friend. Like Doom, there's just something so satisfying about gunning down blocky demons. It's a fast game and you will likely die a lot, but you just respond and do a little better next time. Each level is full of secrets and fun to explore. Quake also goes on sale for super cheap so yeah, go run around and kill some monsters

title: Shadows Over Loathing
description: Shadows Over Loathing — a slapstick-figure comedy adventure-RPG full of mobsters, monsters, and mysteries. Mobsters, monsters, and mysteries — welcome to Shadows Over Loathing, the shady side of an already black-and-white world, and a follow-up to the award-winning West of Loathing.

myData.review: The characters are stick figures, and yet, the game still lags on the Switch. And double yet, I'm still giving this game a 4. That's how much I liked it. This may be the only video game that I actually find funny. It's so over the top and absurd, but it also has a kind of slapstick corny charm. There is a good amount of customization you can do with your character both in terms of build and dialogue options. There is a narrator who you can sometimes disagree with, leading to strange meta-game goofiness. There are bird chirps that sometimes sing to the music. The RPG elements are also done pretty well here; there are places to explore, stuff to collect, strange enemies to fight. It's not a game for everyone, but if you want a light-hearted funny RPG, check this stick out.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
description: Forget everything you know about The Legend of Zelda games. Step into a world of discovery, exploration, and adventure in The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild, a boundary-breaking new game in the acclaimed series. Travel across vast fields, through forests, and to mountain peaks as you discover what has become of the kingdom of Hyrule in this stunning Open-Air Adventure. Now on Nintendo Switch, your journey is freer and more open than ever. Take your system anywhere, and adventure as Link any way you like.
displayTitle: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild

myData.review:
Breath of the Wild is one of the best games you can get on the Switch and the reason many people buy a Switch. It's also my favorite Zelda game since Link to the Past on the SNES. You're given all your abilities in the first couple hours of the game, and at that point, you're allowed to go wherever you want. I loved just running around, exploring and collecting things across the open world of Hyrule. The music is atmospheric and really captures the mood of the game. Breath of the Wild also forces you to experiment and try different weapons and gear. All your weapons break fairly quickly so you need to constantly cycle through different equipment. This might feel a little overwhelming, but you get used to it quick and the interfaces are done well. It's an impressive game, physics-wise. Just about everything is done in-game, with limited cutscenes. In some of the boss area's the entire structure you're in can be rotated. Usually this would be done in a cutscene in a game during which they'd switch out one map for another, but in BOTW everything happens in real time. It's really cool and definitely messes with your perspective. You can jump off any mountain and hang-glide anywhere you want, or shield surf down any hill or mountain (one of my favorite things to do). Whenever I play another open world game now, I'm always wishing I could glide or shield surf. \n

I'm also impressed that BOTW can be totally open world without being an RPG. There are some RPG elements like collecting heart pieces or enhancing your gear, but the rest is up to you.  It's not a perfect game though. One gripe that I had was that the temples were often very similar with one another. And there are a loooot of temples. But overall, this was a great game that is still fun to run around and fight monsters in even after you beat the game.

title: Rayman Legends Definitive Edition
description: Rayman, winner of multiple artistic and musical achievements, is coming to Nintendo Switch™ with Rayman Legends Definitive Edition. Rayman, Globox, and the Teensies are off wandering through an enchanted forest when they discover a mysterious tent filled with a series of captivating paintings. As they look more closely, they notice each painting seems to tell the story of a mythical world. While focusing on a painting that shows a medieval land, they are suddenly sucked into the painting, entering the world, and the adventure begins.

myData.review:
Ok, I know I owe Rayman another chance - I did not get very far. This was my first time playing any Rayman game, but man, I just did not like it. I suppose you could say, that everyone DOESN'T like Rayman... (crickets). \n

Anyways, I found the overworld confusing, though the levels themselves seemed alright. But I think it was the graphics and art style that really did it in for me. There was something almost nauseating about the characters and visuals that was reminiscent of The Stinky Cheeseman book. Maybe the level design and game mechanics are spectacular... maybe (they seemed fine so far). And maybe the best tasting burger in the world looks like a dog turd. I don't know, but I'm not eating it.

title: Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle Gold Edition
description: This game is available for purchase exclusively on Nintendo eShop for Nintendo Switch. Gold Edition includes game and season pass: 8 new solo challenges + 5 co-op maps 16 new weapons. An exclusive world featuring a new hero, coming in early 2018. The Mushroom Kingdom has been torn apart by a mysterious vortex, transporting the chaotic Rabbids into this once-peaceful land. To restore order, Mario, Luigi, Princess Peach, and Yoshi must team up with a whole new crew: four Rabbids heroes! Together, they will battle with weapons through four worlds filled with combat, puzzles, and unpredictable enemies. Developed exclusively for the Nintendo Switch™ system, Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle is the best of the Mario and Rabbids franchises, combining all that you love about Mario's iconic universe with the side-splitting antics of the Rabbids.
displayTitle: Mario + Rabbids Kingdom Battle Gold Edition

myData.review: I don't really get the Rabbids. I guess they're sort of like Minions, which I also don't really get. But I didn't hate them as much as I thought I would, though I definitely almost exclusively played as the Mario cast rather than the Rabbid Mario dress-up characters. It's a pretty fun tactics rpg game with a good amount of exploration and puzzles thrown in in-between levels. The weapon selection isn't super exciting, as you just want to pick the one that does the most damage, but there's a bit of customization you can do with each character in terms of leveling up and skill-trees. The overworld is vast with lots of explore/unlock but also can feel a little sprawling and confusing. The rabbid cutscenes and bosses are all waaaaay over the top, and I felt torn between being entertained and wanting to bleach my eyeballs. I did complete it, and I did buy the next game in the series, so I guess the entertaining part won out, though I still felt like I could use some bleach eyedrops as times.

title: Blasphemous
description: A foul curse has fallen upon the land of Cvstodia and all its inhabitants - it is simply known as The Miracle. Play as The Penitent One - a sole survivor of the massacre of the ‘Silent Sorrow’. Trapped in an endless cycle of death and rebirth, it’s down to you to free the world from this terrible fate and reach the origin of your anguish. Explore this nightmarish world of twisted religion and discover its many secrets hidden deep inside. Use devastating combos and brutal executions to smite the hordes of grotesque monsters and titanic bosses, who are all ready to rip your limbs off. Locate and equip relics, rosary beads and prayers that call on the powers of the heavens to aid you in your quest to break your eternal damnation.

myData.review:
Oh hell yeah! This is a dark, gory, bloody, beautiful game. It takes some of the most twisted and gruesome parts of western religion and subverts them further to build the world this game takes place in. The bosses and NPCs are some of the most creepy creatures imaginable. The music is great, and the pixel graphics are too. 

It's a bit of a slow paced game in terms of your movements and attacks, compared to other recent Metroidvanias. Every action you take must be very deliberate. The game's tends to be on the difficult side, but never gets insanely challenging. The enemy actions can be a little predictable and I did find myself confused on how to progress at times - but overall this is probably my second favorite modern Metroidvania game, second only to Hollow Knight.

title: Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove
description: Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove is the full and complete edition of Shovel Knight, a sweeping classic action-adventure game series with awesome gameplay, memorable characters, and an 8-bit retro aesthetic! Run, jump, and battle as Shovel Knight, wielder of the Shovel Blade, in a quest for his lost beloved. Take down the nefarious knights of the Order of No Quarter and confront their menacing leader, The Enchantress. But that’s not everything! Shovel Knight: Treasure Trove also features four additional games all unto themselves! Take control of Plague Knight, Specter Knight, and King Knight on adventures of their own or battle each other in a local four player Showdown.

myData.review: So I finally got around to playing Shovel Knight, and it was amazing! It's like medieval, silly megaman with great controls and music. Besides Shovel Knight, there were 3 other games here too where you play as some of the bosses each in their own separate adventure. There is a bit of a learning curve for each of them, with the Plague Knight being the most challenging. The graphics and artstyle are definitely in the mold of the NES, but it feels like a brand new game; not something trite or redundant. Each level is fun to play both fast and slow, either sprinting through, or taking your time and exploring. All 4 games were very good, though I did prefer Shovel Knight classic the best. The 3 other adventures, I did like, but also had some mixed feelings about (annoying to change Plague Knights abilities, Specter Knight felt imprecise, etc). Overall, game as a whole was great, though its 40 bucks so maybe wait til there's a sale.

title: Gato Roboto
description: Pounce inside of your cozy armored mech and set off on a dangerous trek through an alien underworld full of irritable creatures and treacherous obstacles in a valiant effort to save your stranded captain and his crashed spaceship. Tiptoe outside the friendly confines of your technological marvel and follow your feline instincts through tight tunnels and mysterious waterways to scavenge for new weapons and gear. Adventure awaits the most curious of cats in Gato Roboto!

myData.review: This was a fun & short action/metroidvania game. It's got black and white charming graphics with retro music. You also play as a cat, which is pretty cute, as are most of the enemy sprites. Graphics are pretty similar to Down Well, if you were into that game. It's fairly short but also fairly cheap. Fun game to beat in a weekend.

title: Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom
description: Enjoy a colorful action-adventure game made alongside Ryuichi Nishizawa, creator of the original Wonder Boy in Monster World series. Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom borrows the best from the classic series to deliver a fresh, modern adventure with fun gameplay, memorable music and gorgeous hand drawn animations. Can Jin save Monster World Kingdom? Help our young hero defeat challenging enemies, discover hidden locations, upgrade powerful equipment, and more! You'll also unlock special forms with unique skills used to open new paths where mighty bosses and secret treasures await.
displayTitle: Monster Boy and the Cursed Kingdom

myData.review: I've never played a Monster Boy game before this one so I went in with fresh eyes.  Basically you play as some kid who can turn into different creatures, each with different abilities, which you unlock as you progress through the game. I guess it's a bit of a Metroidvania game at heart, but the graphics and playstyle felt a little reminiscent of those old internet Flash games. I still played through the whole game, but I never felt like it was particularly gripping or interesting.

title: Eastward
description: Escape the tyrannical clutches of a subterranean society and join Eastward’s unlikely duo on an exciting adventure to the land above! Discover beautiful yet bizarre settlements and make new friends as you travel across the world by rail. Combine John and Sam’s skills to solve dungeon puzzles, take down unusual enemies, and survive the deadly miasma. Can you uncover the truth behind Sam’s mystic powers and bring back harmony to Eastward’s ravaged lands?

myData.review: So I only played the demo. But why do they gotta talk so much? Good lord... I liked the graphics and music, and the parts that felt like an action RPG seemed cool. But then there seemed to be an obscene amount of dialogue. So, I guess I don't quite know what this game is trying to be. And that's ok. But for me, the fun parts were few and far between, so I'm afraid this one will have to just stay a demo.

title: Celeste
description: Help Madeline survive her inner demons on her journey to the top of Celeste Mountain, in this super-tight, hand-crafted platformer from the creators of multiplayer classic TowerFall. A narrative-driven, single-player adventure like mom used to make, with a charming cast of characters and a touching story of self-discovery.

myData.review:
Celeste is a simple that is executed extremely well. The art style and music are shrouded in retro pixelated love without feeling cheesy or derivative. Character movement feels super tight which is definitely needed because this game gets haaaaard. It's a challenging game with a story about overcoming personal challenges - so smart! There aren't a lot of scenes or dialog in the game, but what was there I found very powerful and moving. 

I can't really talk about this game without talking about the difficulty aspect. As I mentioned above, this is a tough game and you will die a lot. I didn't really find it frustrating though, maybe because there weren't really any cheap kills or gotcha mechanics thrown in. There are also constant save points, so you are really just clearing one room at a time. I definitely 100% complete this game, but then again, I'm not sure anyone actually has. So if I like this game so much, why not give it a 5? Well, I'm trying to really reserve those... but maybe I should. I don't really have any 'dings' against the game - maybe it could have been a little longer? Why I'm keeping it 4 is mostly the lack of innovation and a "wow" factor. At the end of the day, it's just another 2D platformer with really good music. It just happens to be one of the best 2D platformers with really good music.

title: Valfaris & Slain Double Pack
description: Experience two of the most metal games ever made in this gore-drenched double-pack from Big Sugar and developer Steel Mantis. This bundle contains cult hit Slain: Back From Hell, and the critically acclaimed Valfaris.

myData.review: So I played Valfaris for a bit and Slain hardly at all. I really enjoyed Valfaris, it's like a 2D platformer shooter where you collect different weapons and can level them up a bit along the way. It gets difficult pretty quick but there are plenty of checkpoints so you never have to backtrack too much. I always thought the main character looked kinda like John Romero which makes sense for a bloody shooter where you use giant guns. Anyways, Valfaris was fun, though I didn't finish it. I didn't really give Slain much of a chance, but I didn't love it right away. I think this duo pack goes on sale pretty often, so if you like indie retro bloody platformers, this is a pretty good get.

title: Borderlands: Game of the Year Edition
description: Discover the co-op shooter-looter that started it all, crammed with content and enhancements! Equip bazillions of guns as one of 4 trigger-happy mercenaries, each with unique RPG skills. Take on the lawless desolate planet Pandora in pursuit of powerful alien technology: The Vault. With new weapons, visual upgrades, all 4 add-on packs and more! • Bazillions of Guns: Rocket-launching shotguns, enemy-torching revolvers, SMGs that fire lightning rounds, and tons more. • Radical Art Style: Traditional rendering combined with hand-drawn textures give Borderlands its iconic style. • Intense Vehicular Combat: Behind the wheel, engage in frenetic vehicle-to-vehicle combat. • Co-op Frenzy: Online or together on the couch.
displayTitle: Borderlands: Game of the Year Edition

title: Pokémon Shield
description: A new generation of Pokémon is coming to the Nintendo Switch™ system. Begin your adventure as a Pokémon Trainer by choosing one of three new partner Pokémon: Grookey, Scorbunny, or Sobble. Then embark on a journey in the new Galar region, where you’ll challenge the troublemakers of Team Yell, while unraveling the mystery behind the Legendary Pokémon Zacian and Zamazenta! Explore the Wild Area, a vast expanse of land where the player can freely control the camera. Team up with three other players locally or online in the new multiplayer co-op Max Raid Battles* in which players will face off against gigantic and super-strong Pokémon known as Dynamax Pokémon.

myData.review: Game Freak has basically been making the same Pokemon game every few years since the original Red/Blue versions. Now that I type all that out, I kind of wish more games would do this - I would love a basic Mario or Sonic 2D platformer every other year. But I don't feel that way about Pokemon. Every Pokemon game I've played feels simultaneously fun but disappointing. I definitely enjoy the collecting and leveling up/evolving aspect, but it's that same old crusty battle system that really needs a makeover. The best new feature in Sword/Shield was definitely the open area more or less in the middle of the map. I hope this is an indication of the direction they're going with the new games. Being able to walk around and explore big open worlds and see and catch Pokemon in the wild has always been the dream. That and them switching to more an action rpg system rather than the turn based.\n While I'm here, here's another big gripe I have with these games. I breeze through the main game because you fight trainers who literally pick a random move with no strategy whatsoever. Then I get to the after game challenge section and I get destroyed. And I realize all along I was supposed to be caring about all these hidden variables like EVs and I should have been leveling up my Pokemon slowly, only fighting the right enemies, etc. There's no way I'm putting in the effort for all that, but why is there no middle ground between these 2 extremes of difficulty and playstyle?

title: Shantae: Half-Genie Hero
description: Shantae embarks on her first full HD adventure! When a mysterious crime wave sweeps Sequin Land, it’s up to Half-Genie Hero Shantae to save the day!
