Use Shantae’s devastating Hair-Whip Attack to send monsters flying, or Belly Dance to transform into a more powerful creature form! Topple the masterminds behind each criminal caper and prepare for the ultimate showdown against Shantae’s arch nemesis: the bodacious buccaneer Risky Boots!

myData.review: This is my first Shantae game, and honestly I didn't really get the appeal. It has an early 2000s internet Flash game kinda feel. I thought the levels were poorly designed and graphics and music kind of hokey. Maybe I would enjoy it more if I was a 12 year old. It's not like it was terrible. Some of the bosses were cool. But it was just kind of has this kiddie Metroidvania-light feel, with nothing special about it besides maybe the characters? But I'm not 12 so I didn't really vibe with the cartoony aspect of it all.

title: Sea of Stars
description: Sea of Stars tells the story of two Children of the Solstice who combine the powers of the sun and moon to perform Eclipse Magic, the only force capable of fighting off the monstrous creations of an evil alchemist known as The Fleshmancer.

myData.review: Sea of Stars is another game I thought was pretty good overall, but also fairly disappointing. The graphics and music are great - it's in the mold of some classic SNES rpgs (Chrono Trigger graphics with a Mario RPG playstyle). But I found the combat & move selection lacking and the story and characters generic and fairly annoying. There is one character in particular who I could not stand, and yet half the game the other characters are talking about how great they are. Overall, it was mostly a fun experience - I got all the conchs and all that. The artstyle, graphics, and soundtrack were all excellent and exploration/combat was all executed pretty well. But ultimately for me, the game as a whole fell flat.

I love a good tactics game and Fire Emblem definitely delivered on that front. It had everything I want with this type of game: lots of characters, old school graphics... I guess that's about it honestly. Of course, as is JRPG tactics tradition, the dialogue goes on wayyyy too long. It's mostly skippable, and you better believe I was smashing that skip button because I stopped caring about the story after maybe the 2nd mission. Combat is very reminiscent of Shining Force - one of my favorite Sega games. However, there is no world to explore. It's just chatting and fighting. I was warned that this game gets tough, and I definitely died a few times (but you can just restart the mission). It's not a game you can really grind your way up a few levels as there are no random enemy battles. However, there are a couple arenas within certain levels where you can squeeze out a good amount of XP for characters you care about. So yeah, if you have the Switch Advanced membership and access to the GBA software, check this one out for a good tactics game.

title: Kirby’s Return to Dream Land Deluxe
description: The tough puff Kirby is back for a 1-4 player platforming adventure across Planet Popstar. Help Magolor rebuild his ship with newly added Mecha and Sand Copy Abilities!
displayTitle: Kirby’s Return to Dream Land Deluxe

myData.review: I wasn't sure whether to give this a 3 or a 4. There are 3 parts to this game: The main game, a bunch of mini games you can unlock, and a short bonus game where you play as a different character. Kirby always kind of makes for an awkward character to play a platformer with. He's so floaty and sluggish that it's often just easier to fly over most of the level rather than play through it the "normal way". Return to Dreamland was definitely on the easy side, and honestly I was kind of sick of it about halfway through. It picked up a bit at the end though. The minigames were pretty expansive, almost rivaling Mario Party and probably would be pretty fun in a group. I also really liked the bonus game which I played after beating the main game. You play as one of the enemy characters - I don't remember which one, and slowly gain back their strength. It's short, but I kind of liked it more than then main game.

title: Yoku's Island Express
description: Yoku has arrived on Mokumana and he’s ready for the easy life, soaking up the sun and delivering parcels on a tropical paradise! However, an ancient Island deity is trapped in a restless sleep - and it’s all down to Yoku to traverse the island using a unique blend of pinball mechanics, platforming and open world exploration, in an amazing adventure to help those in need!

myData.review: Yoku's Island Express was a really cute interesting take on pretty much a Metroidvania type of game. The hook here is that you're playing pinball. You play as Yoku (who is a bug or something I think?) and also acts as the pinball itself. You have some control over left/right movement and can maybe jump I think?  But then you also have the paddles where you have to flick poor Yoku up series of winding paths and ramps. It can be fun, and it can also be a little repetitive or annoying at times, since you have to replay tricky parts several times if you fall from a ways up. But it's a pretty short game and never super difficult or anything. And it's bright, colorful, unique, charming, with some pretty catchy music. I hope they make another one, since it is a pretty unique style of play and I think a little bit of fine-tuning and game expansion could go a long way.

title: DOOM Eternal
description: DOOM® Eternal, the award-winning game and “one of the best first-person shooters ever” according to GameRevolution, is coming to Nintendo Switch. Developed by id Software and Panic Button, DOOM Eternal is the direct sequel to DOOM®, winner of The Game Awards’ Best Action Game of 2016. Hell’s armies have invaded Earth. Become the Slayer in an epic single-player campaign to conquer demons across dimensions and stop the final destruction of humanity. The only thing they fear…is you.

myData.review: So, TBH I did not finish this game. It seems like online people tend to like this game more than Doom 2016. But for me, the fast paced, low overhead magic that existed in Doom 2016 was kind of stripped away here. Yes, the action is still intense, and the music and art and gameplay is still awesome. But right away, the first thing that appears on the home screen is the game prompting you to sign into your Bethesda account. I forget if you have to do this to play or not, but I think you might. And then the overworld has you on this big ship that feels a little confusing and a lot of boring. There's also a lot more story in this game, and I found it a good deal harder right off the bat. Something about those combinations of things made me lose my appetite for demon slaying. Instead of fast paced slaughtering, I found myself teetering between boredom and frustration. I have been meaning to pick this back up, and maybe it gets better as the game goes on. But having just come from Doom 2016, I was pretty disappointed.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom
description: An epic adventure awaits in the Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom game, only on the Nintendo Switch system. In this sequel to the Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild game, you’ll decide your own path through the sprawling landscapes of Hyrule and the mysterious islands floating in the vast skies above. Can you harness the power of Link’s new abilities to fight back against the malevolent forces that threaten the kingdom?
displayTitle: The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom

myData.review:
Yeah... go ahead and take my 5 star rating TOTK. Let's start with the positives - It's a better story than BOTW, with slightly better gameplay than the first game and impressive physics. You can create vehicles, seesaws, crazy weapons, traps, whatever you want really - though the crafting system can be tedious and imprecise. I love how much of the game they keep in the in-game engine. You don't create a vehicle or pulley system to move some guy around and then cutscene magic happens. Everything happens within the engine of the game. It's definitely impressive. The game is also huge with 3 layers of maps stacked on top of one another. You got your normal walkin' around part with villages, you got your sky islands, and then you got your huge underground cave area. What's great about these new Zelda games is how fun it is to just mess around, explore, and experiment \n

Now onto why I gave this a reluctant 5/5. Yes, it is bigger and better than BOTW, but why oh why did they choose to set the game in the exact same location only like 10 years in the future. I know there are sky islands and underground caves, but the main map is the same map as the last game! That's really my main issue, is that in the 6 years between games, why did they keep so many things the same. You explore the same towns, you fight the 4 bosses, then you fight Ganondorf. Another gripe is that the underground world is so big but so homogenous. It's beautiful and eerie and there's some cool stuff down there, but there's also a lot of areas that all look and feel exactly the same. So yeah, great game, fun game, but for god sake please give us a new map with less caves for the next game.

title: Sonic Origins
description: Relive the classic collected adventures of Sonic The Hedgehog, Sonic The Hedgehog 2, Sonic 3 & Knuckles, and Sonic CD in the newly remastered Sonic Origins! From the iconic Green Hill Zone to the treacherous Death Egg Robot, you'll speed down memory lane to thwart the sinister plans of Doctor Robotnik in polished high definition! This latest version includes new areas to explore, exclusive animations, and a brand new Anniversary mode! Classic Re-Defined Explore the classic Sonic titles in high-resolution, with all-new opening and ending animations for each title!

myData.review:
Sonic Origins is basically a collection of 5 games - Sonic 1, Sonic 2, Sonic 3, Sonic & Knuckles, and Sonic CD. These are some of my absolute favorite games, and in my estimation, some of the best 2D platformers ever. The extra stuff on Sonic Origins besides the huge collection of concept art is essentially negligible. The achievements and challenges feel like they're tossed in last minute, and the overworld menu is pretty blah. I did of course get all the achievements and played through each game twice. The games all play great (not always the case for 3rd party Switch games), and you can change the resolution if you want to be a purist. The game I was far most excited for was Sonic CD as I've only played through that game once back when I was a teenager. Sonic CD plays most similarly to Sonic 1. It has a darker aesthetic than the other games, and the music is amazing. The bonus levels and time travel stuff was a little annoying though. Sometimes you'd accidentally travel to the future because you couldn't stop running. But Sonic CD really focuses on exploring each level which I appreciated. \n

I was never sure which of the original Sonic game was my favorite - I liked the pacing of 1, the epicness of 2, the bonus shields of 3, and the narrative of S&K. However playing though each one twice in a row this time around helped shed some clarity on that pondery. So, ranking the Sonic games (drumroll....) goes as such. #1) Sonic 2 - it's not perfect but it is such a fun full game with a big variety of levels. #2) Sonic 1 - I love this game so much. It's the slowest paced game of the Sonics, but I really love exploring each level. #3) Sonic 3 - Love the shield upgrades. Takes the physics of Sonic 2 and makes them a little tighter, but feels a little short. #4) Sonic CD - the time travel stuff can be a little frustrating, but it's also very satisfying exploring and saving the future of each stage. #5) Sonic & Knuckles - I know that you can play 3 into Sonic & Knuckles - which I usually do. And I do like getting all the hyper emeralds for the different characters. Why it's my least favorite has to do with the levels - there's a claustrophobic-ness and a segmentation to the stages that overall make the game less enjoyable than the others.

title: Pokémon UNITE
description: Join Trainers from around the world as they head for Aeos Island to compete in Unite Battles! In Unite Battles, Trainers face off in 5-on-5 team battles to see who can score the most points within the allotted time. Teamwork is key as you and your teammates defeat wild Pokémon, level up and evolve your partner Pokémon, and knock out the opposing team’s Pokémon to prevent them from scoring points. Put your teamwork to the test, and take home the win!

myData.review: Other than Solitaire or Minesweeper, I tend to be very anti free games. Most of them feel scammy and purposefully addictive and like I'm being sold to the whole time I'm playing. There's a bit of that here with Pokemon Unite, but as far as free games go, this is one of the better ones. It's basically taking the old DOTA/League of Legends one team vs another format and simplifying/shortening it. I enjoyed this game for a few weeks and it's kind of fun with friends too. What is a little annoying with games in this type of DOTA format, is that the strategy to win becomes so specific (at minute 2 go here, and minute 5 down here, etc) So that can get a little frustrating and a little old. But I still enjoyed this game for a couple weeks.

title: TOEM
description: Set off on a delightful expedition and use your photographic eye to uncover the mysteries of the magical TOEM in this hand-drawn adventure game. Chat with quirky characters, solve their problems by snapping neat photos, and make your way through a relaxing landscape! Key Features Take photos with your camera to solve puzzles and help people! Listen to chill beats and take in your surroundings! Meet quirky characters and help them with their problems!

myData.review: I love that video games like TOEM exist nowadays. This is a great end of the night kind of game that is low stakes, only requiring some light puzzle solving. The basic concept is you go around and take pictures of things to progress through the levels. Sometimes it's just about exploring and looking for a certain object, and other times it's more about convincing some guy to move out of the way. It's cute and quirky, without getting too over the top or meta. I really liked the artstyle and general vibes of TOEM. It just kind of put me in a chill, laid back mood. And it's a game you can play for 5 minutes or an hour; there's no real commitment cost. It's a fairly short game, and some of the photo quests were more interesting than others, but if you can pick this up on sale, I'd highly recommend TOEM.

title: SteamWorld Dig 2
description: SteamWorld Dig 2 takes you on a platform mining adventure forged in Metroidvania flames. When an old trading town is struck by mysterious earthquakes, it’s up to a lone steambot and her unlikely companion to uncover what trembling terrors lie beneath. Dig your way underground and explore vivid worlds riddled with treasure, secrets and traps.

myData.review: All the SteamWorld games I've played have been solid. And this is the one I think that really made the series pop. It plays a little like if there was a Metroidvania version of the Mario 2 desert level. SteamWorld Dig 2 was a fun little playthrough but I didn't find it particularly special or interesting. Gameplay was good, graphics were good, but nothing was great. I also have some mixed feelings about the artstyle and aesthetics. It's like robot steampunk but kind of cheesy? It can be charming at times but sophomoric at others.

title: Cult of the Lamb
description: Crusade through dungeons, slay heretics, build your cult, and seek new powers together. But there’s more. As well as the addition of co-op play, the Unholy Alliance expansion also adds new tarot cards, relics, buildings, fleeces, follower traits, follower quests, and other secrets to discover!

myData.review: This game was ok. I liked the half roguelike, half farm simulator idea, but the fighting part was definitely a lot more fun than the farming part. Combat mechanics and gameplay were pretty good (not amazing), but the farming aspect just got pretty stale -- having to collect everything and all that. I did enjoy the cult spin on everything. You had these little animal followers who you could brainwash, sacrifice, resurrect, etc. And all the sprites were pretty cute. The biggest downfall though was that the game crashed several times and towards the very end got a little sluggish. So, gotta subtract a point for that from what could have been a decent game. Maybe plays better on the computer? I dunno, it's not like it's a must play either way.

title: Axiom Verge 2
description: The long awaited sequel to Axiom Verge, Axiom Verge 2 expands on the universe with completely new characters, abilities, and gameplay.

myData.review: Oof, this game was disappointing. I remember loving the first Axiom Verge. That game, along with Hallow Knight and others got me obsessed with Metroidvania games for a few years. The new mechanics in Axiom Verge 2 are more annoying than interesting - the big one being launching a little robot guy you can control. The overall mode and style just seems like it's missing something. It's not as fun and quirky as the first game, instead it feels more dry and sterile. That said, if you like Metroidvanias, this one plays well on the switch a will be a decent play. It just won't be a great play.

title: Mortal Kombat 11
description: Mortal Kombat 11 is the latest installment in the critically acclaimed franchise, providing a deeper and more personalized experience than ever before. The all new Custom Character Variations give you unprecedented control of your fighters to make them your own. Featuring a roster of new and returning Klassic Fighters, Mortal Kombat's best-in-class cinematic story mode continues the epic saga over 25 years in the making.

myData.review: I enjoyed this game for a bit, but got tired of it pretty quick. I guess the combat was alright, but I was never too big into these types of 1v1 fighting games. Some of the extra bits, like the unlockable costume parts and the huge dungeon where you run around and open chests of more unlockables seemed compelling at first, but ultimately ended up feeling like hollow gimmicks. All the backstories and cutscenes with the characters in the one-player mission mode, I just really didn't care about. The story I think seemed to involve family drama mixed with like time traveling aliens or something? Does anyone care about that stuff in a fighting game? Why don't they just try and make the game good?

title: Super Mario Odyssey
description: Explore incredible places far from the Mushroom Kingdom as you join Mario and his new ally Cappy on a massive, globe-trotting 3D adventure. Use amazing new abilities—like the power to capture and control objects, animals, and enemies—to collect Power Moons so you can power up the Odyssey airship and save Princess Peach from Bowser’s wedding plans!

myData.review:
Ok now we're dealing with the big boys. We're talking big boy stuff here. But really though, this is maybe the best game on the Switch. (I feel like I've compared just about every other game on this list to Odyssey.) The levels have this nice open feeling that promote exploration and experimentation, inspired greatly by one of the greatest Mario games, Mario 64. The big issue I had with the 3D Mario games that came out in between 64 and Odyssey (ie Mario Galaxy) was how linear, segmented, and boxed in they all felt. In Mario Odyssey you get these nice big boy levels you can just play around in. Triple jump into a wall jump into a dive, long jump off a cliff and save yourself by throwing your hat into an enemy. Oh yeah, the big new thing with Mario Odyssey is that you can throw your hat into things and change into them. Some are definitely more fun than others (gliding lizard > tree). My favorite was the caterpillar. \n

But the best part of the game in my opinion was the freedom of movement in the levels. It's a sizable game with over 800 moons to collect, but it's not a giant game as far as modern games go. I honestly could have used another level or 2. One other thing just to gripe on is the music in most of these modern Nintendo games. I really feel like the best Mario music came out on the NES and SNES, I credit this to the severe limitations of the hardware at the time. Because they couldn't have many layers of instruments or even many different timbres or sounds, old Mario games had these amazing unique catchy themes, often in this spastic ragtime style. Where as with the new games, where possibilities of orchestration and timbres are endless, Nintendo music often focuses more on instrumentation, layers, and symphonic textures. One exception is the Stream Gardens theme. That's just a fun tune. I know this is mostly a preference of aesthetics, but I really don't care much for this professional symphonic sound so many of the levels seemed to have. Anyways, great game, maybe the best game on the Switch. Pretty much a must have.

title: Neon White
description: Neon White is a lightning fast first-person action game about exterminating demons in Heaven. You are White, an assassin handpicked from Hell to compete with other demon slayers for a chance to live permanently in Heaven. The other assassins seem familiar, though… did you know them in a past life? Features: • You play as Neon White, an assassin plucked from Hell to compete with other demon slayers for a shot at redemption. • Collect “Soul Cards” to attack your foes or discard them to use unique movement abilities. • Compete for the best times by cleverly combining cards to discover massive shortcuts. • Uncover Heaven’s mysteries by getting to know the other assassins… did you know them in a past life?

myData.review: Neon White was pretty fun. It's like a speed-running streamlined FPS mixed with a Japanese dating simulator. It plays really well, and with the missions being so short, it's pretty fun trying to sprint through each of them and get the platinum score in each level. I wasn't all that interested in the inbetween level conversations and gift giving with the other characters, though there were some extra levels you could unlock, and I did like the cat that smoked a cigar. Online, I felt like people were pretty stoked about the gameplay, which was fun, but I wasn't blown away by any of it. Was it really doing anything that much more innovative than Doom was 30 years ago (besides jumping)?

title: Minit
description: Minit is a peculiar little adventure played sixty seconds at a time. Journey outside the comfort of your home to help unusual folk, uncover countless secrets, and overcome dangerous foes, all in hopes of lifting a rather unfortunate curse that ends each day after just one minute. Minit is a collaboration between Kitty Calis, Jan Willem Nijman, Jukio Kallio & Dominik Johann.

myData.review: Minit is a fun, short adventure game where you only have 1 minute to go search the world before you die and have to start again. In that one minute you basically run around trying to find new weapons and abilities and figure out how to progress to the next starting location. It has a charming artstyle and graphics and although based around a gimmicky concept, it plays like nice little mini-adventure game. It's not very long, but I'm pretty sure it goes on sale for a buck or 2.

title: Fall Guys
description: Fall Guys is a free, cross-platform massively multiplayer party royale game. Clumsily compete in absurd obstacle courses with friends or build your very own chaotic course to share with the community.

myData.review: I mean, it's free and I had fun the couple times I played it, but I don't see myself going back to this game anytime soon, especially on my own. But if you want a quick silly multiplayer game, try it out. It's fun, but definitely not the most fun.

title: Dicey Dungeons
description: In this new fast-paced deckbuilding roguelike from Terry Cavanagh, Chipzel, and Marlowe Dobbe, you'll fight monsters, find better loot, and level up your heroes as you work together to take down the Goddess of Fortune, Lady Luck herself. Balance your carefully planned strategies against the unknown of a dice roll. Play as six different characters, each with their own unique play styles and abilities. Master each class and figure out which one best fits your style in this charming world filled with a growing array of twists and secrets. Can you make it out alive? Maybe, but luck is definitely not on your side.

myData.review: It's fine. I played this on steam a while back and after watching some friends play it recently, I thought "yeah, that looks fun, why did I stop playing that?" And then I played it, and I remembered why. I really like the idea of dice mechanics in RPG combat and I think this could have been expanded upon more in interesting ways. But while Dicey Dungeons may be fun the first time or 2 playing through, it gets old pretty quick. It's a fairly short game without a ton of variety. And I really don't like the graphics or music at all. But if you're bored with 20 min to kill I suppose there are worst ways to spend your time.

title: Don't Starve Together
description: Don't Starve Together is the standalone multiplayer expansion of the uncompromising wilderness survival game, Don't Starve. Enter a strange and unexplored world full of strange creatures, dangers, and surprises. Gather resources to craft items and structures that match your survival style. Play your way as you unravel the mysteries of this strange land. Cooperate with your friends in a private game, or take your chances with strangers online. Work with other players to survive the harsh environment, or strike out on your own. Do whatever it takes, but most importantly, Don't Starve.

myData.review: It's always confused me why Don't Starve Together had to be a separate game from Don't Starve? Maybe that's not so much a thing anymore, but i digress. I only played this game a little with some friends online and it was pretty fun. The game played well, and its a good game to chat with pals while building up a little campsite/looking for berries/running from eyeball monsters. I've always found Don't Starve to be a pretty challenging game and I've never been able to get super far, but I've always enjoyed the times I've played it.

title: Mario Kart 8 Deluxe
description: Hit the road with the definitive version of Mario Kart 8 and play anytime, anywhere! Race your friends or battle them in a revised battle mode on new and returning battle courses. Play locally in up to 4-player multiplayer in 1080p while playing in TV Mode. Every track from the Wii U version, including DLC, makes a glorious return. Plus, the Inklings appear as all-new guest characters, along with returning favorites, such as King Boo, Dry Bones, and Bowser Jr.!

myData.review: I mean, Mario Kart is one of the reasons you buy the Switch. Yes, I'm aware this came out on the Wii-U, and yes it's annoying that to play the new roster of extra levels you need to be a Switch Online+ (or whatever it's called) subscriber, but it's still one of the best multiplayer games out there that's always fun to come back to. It's also one of the only modern Multiplayer games that just about everyone can enjoy, from skilled players to filthy casuals. I was a bit overwhelmed at first with all the loops and the colors and the hovering and the flying and the jello pudding cups (sorry don't know what came over me), but I got used to it pretty quick. So yeah, Mario Kart is a Nintendo classic for a reason, dating back to the SNES, and it's basically expected to have this in your collection.

title: Tunic
description: Explore a land filled with lost legends, ancient powers, and ferocious monsters in TUNIC, an isometric action game about a small fox on a big adventure. Stranded in a ruined land, and armed with only your own curiosity, you will confront colossal beasts, collect strange and powerful items, and unravel long-lost secrets.

myData.review: I did not love Tunic, but I did appreciate Tunic. It's a game that kind of takes a while to see the real payoff. I would describe Tunic as kind of a puzzle adventure game. It plays a tiny bit like an isometric Zelda Link to the Past, but finding where to go next and how to proceed is the tricky and at times frustrating part. But the game play is not where the real magic of Tunic lies. That instead lies in the layers of secrets and hidden codes/messages throughout the game. The main gimmick is that you're collecting pieces of an instruction manual or player's guide on how to play tunic throughout the world. You find the pages in a seemingly random order and a lot of the instructions are in a made up language that only through context, and images can you kind of figure out what you're supposed to be doing. You will run into a lot of dead ends and that can be pretty confusing, but it can also be incredibly rewarding figuring out some puzzle or secret from deciphering the instructions. (Side note: the instruction manual is the cutest instruction manual of all time.) I definitely did not figure out all the puzzles or get all the collectables as the secrets go deep. Even some of the music had secret messages decoded in them, but I think you needed outside tools to decipher it. Anyways, it was a cool game, but also a challenging game that takes some patience.

title: Super Mario Maker 2
description: Mario fans of the world, unite! Now you can play, create, and share the side-scrolling Super Mario™ courses of your dreams in the Super Mario Maker™ 2 game, available exclusively on the Nintendo Switch™ system! Dive into the single-player Story Mode and play built-in courses to rebuild Princess Peach’s castle. Make your own courses, alone or together. And with a Nintendo Switch Online membership*, share your courses, access a near-endless supply made by others, enjoy online multiplayer, and more!

myData.review:
Oh how I love to make mario levels. You know, there are a lot of jobs out there that I think, 'yeah I could probably do that'. Most of the time I'm wrong, like very very wrong. But I really do think I would be a great level designer. My biggest problem with Mario Maker is the user submitted levels and the interface used to navigate through this ocean of human garbage they call user created levels. It is so hard to find good levels on here. It's just a cluster of madness. One issue is that novelty and insanity is greatly rewarded among the user levels so that the most extreme levels receive the most attention and are the easiest to find. This means levels with qualities like nuance, playability, and fun are pushed to the side. If you are willing to dig there are some great user submitted levels with a lot of heart. But along the way you will find a lot of 'Xtreme' challenges, and levels where you literally don't press any buttons called 'autoplay'. Really, that's a whole category. Are these fun after trying one of them? \n

Oh yeah, the level editor is great by the way. I just wish the level browser was as well.

title: DARK SOULS™: REMASTERED
description: Re-experience the critically acclaimed, genre-defining game that started it all. Beautifully remastered, return to Lordran in stunning detail. DARK SOULS: REMASTERED includes the main game plus the Artorias of the Abyss DLC. This marks the franchise’s debut on a Nintendo platform, and for the first time ever can be played on-the-go with Nintendo Switch. Deep and Dark Universe— Delve into an epic dark fantasy universe stricken by the Curse. Explore its intricate world design, full of hidden passages, dungeons and secrets.

title: Vampire Survivors
description: Vampire Survivors is a time survival game with minimalistic gameplay and roguelite elements. Mow down thousands of night creatures and survive until dawn! Vampire Survivors is a gothic horror casual game with rogue-lite elements, where your choices can allow you to quickly snowball against the hundreds of monsters that get thrown at you.

myData.review: Vampire Survivors is dumb as hell. It's just enemy & projectile overload. All the shooting is done for you, so the only thing you control is the movement. Run around and slaughter hundreds of enemies and collect power-ups to get even more projectiles. There is just an excessive amount of stuff on the screen at all times. I had fun with it for a while, unlocking the different characters and levels, but it's pretty dang repetitive. I did appreciate the old-school graphics and and spooky monster aesthetics though. Fun for a bit, and it sells for 5 bucks so not a lot to lose.

title: Super Mario Bros. Wonder
description: Classic Mario gameplay is turned on its head with Wonder Flowers in the Super Mario Bros. Wonder game! These game-changing items can make some wonderfully weird stuff happen. Witness pipes coming alive, wreak havoc as a giant Spike-Ball, and lots more!

myData.review: Fiiiiinally they release a 2D Mario game for the Switch and they make it trippy as hell. It's pretty amazing that in every single level they find a unique way to transform the level into a ridiculous psychedelic experience whenever you nab a wonder seed. Sometimes you'd turn into an enemy, sometimes the entire levels perspective would change, and sometimes there'd be a whole musical number. It's pure madness, but at the same time, it still captures the fun, classic 2D mario experience similar to the New Super Mario bros games that came out on Wii. And sure the original Mario 3 for the NES is still my favorite Mario game, and sure part of me wishes Nintendo would forgo all the gimmicks and just make a really good classic Mario game with better graphics and a ton of levels. But then I saw dancing singing piranha plants. And that's why I like Gremlins 2 more than Gremlins 1... Sorry, what was I talking about? Gremlins singing "New York New York"? Ohhh Mario Wonder, my bad. Yeah, that game was fun. And it's multiplayer, and challenging at the end. And it's silly, like very silly. Maybe too silly...? Nahhhh

title: Xenoblade Chronicles 3
description: A vast world awaits in Xenoblade Chronicles 3, the next game in the acclaimed RPG series from developer MONOLITHSOFT. Players will step into the roles of protagonists Noah and Mio amid turmoil between the hostile nations of Keves and Agnus. Six characters hailing from those nations will take part in a grand tale with “life” as its central theme. Explore a new world that will connect the futures of both Xenoblade Chronicles and Xenoblade Chronicles 2, launching for Nintendo Switch in September 2022.

esrbDescriptors: May contain content inappropriate for children. Visit www.esrb.org for rating information.

title: SteamWorld Heist: Ultimate Edition
description: In SteamWorld Heist you command robot pirates in epic tactical shootouts. It’s turn-based strategy with an action twist: By manually aiming your weapons you'll pull off insane bullet-bouncing trick shots!

myData.review: SteamWorld Heist is definitely my favorite of the SteamWorld games I've played. It's a 2D tactics RPG, a pretty rare genre type that I wish more games did more of. You collect and unlock different characters and weapons as you progress and each level can be explored for gold and treasure. I loved trying out all the different characters as I tried to keep them all around the same level. My favorite was the melee fish robot. The game wasn't exactly hard, but it wasn't easy either. I really did have to plan my team and think about each move. I enjoyed all the different characters you encounter, but felt like there was an overkill of dialogue. I also did not care for the music they played at the saloons/shops, but I suppose that's more of a personal gripe.

title: CHRONO CROSS: THE RADICAL DREAMERS EDITION
description: "CHRONO CROSS: THE RADICAL DREAMERS EDITION" is a remaster of "CHRONO CROSS". The 3D models have been upgraded to HD, new illustrations have added, and all kinds of new features are now included. Additionally, the game that formed the bedrock of the story, "RADICAL DREAMERS - Le Trésor Interdit -", is included in this edition! CHRONO CROSS is an RPG that transcends time and space, unfolding across two interlinked parallel worlds. With over 40 party members to meet, people and dimensions will intertwine in this epic drama about the planet itself.
displayTitle: CHRONO CROSS: THE RADICAL DREAMERS EDITION

myData.review:
This game definitely took some getting used to. It's not nearly as straightforward and polished as the original Chrono Trigger, which already wasn't very straightforward. Also, this game is going to feel nothing like the original Chrono Trigger just fyi. I felt like I was constantly confused with Chrono Cross on where I'm supposed to be going. And I couldn't even begin to follow the story. Of course being for the original playstation, these graphics aged like a fine cheese. There are also some weird new combat mechanics thrown in which don't feel like they add that much. 

So is there anything redeeming about this worthless piece of crap of a game that I'm describing? Well yeah actually, and maybe try and mellow out a bit (yikes!) The best parts about this game come down to variety in character choices and all secrets there are to discover. See there are a ton of characters all over the place in this game. Finding them can depend on what year you're in and your previous actions. There are a ton that I did not find. But I had a lot of fun trying out and experimenting with the ones that I did. Some of them even evolve! (What does that remind me of...) So yeah, it's a quirky game with a lot of mystery. But with a little bit of patience, Chrono Cross can be a pretty fun and rewarding experience.

title: DRAGON QUEST XI S: Echoes of an Elusive Age
description: You are the Luminary, the hunted hero who will protect the land from destruction in the latest RPG from the iconic DRAGON QUEST® series. With a ragtag band of adventurers, you’ll engage in well-balanced, turn-based battles and embark on quests across the kingdom of Erdrea. Forge gear, develop party members’ skills, and alter their outfits without changing gear in this edition of the game! This version also lets you ride and attack with monsters on the field to earn experience points, as well as change between HD or 16-bit visuals, symphonic or synth music, and English or Japanese audio.
displayTitle: DRAGON QUEST XI S: Echoes of an Elusive Age

myData.review: If you want a big ol stinkin RPG that doesn't take itself too seriously on the Switch, Dragon Quest 11 is your game. It's really like 3 different games, or long chapters maybe. The 1st one being probably the best, the 2nd being a little sluggish, and the 3rd being the most ridiculous. I don't really remember the story too well, but I'm pretty sure there are aliens thrown in, and you turn into a fish at some point. There's also some secret level stuff where you play in 2D which is kinda fun. Speaking of 2D, you can toggle back and forth between 3D and old school 2D graphics on the fly which is pretty insane they have the game totally mapped out in both environments. As far as the art and music, all I can really say is 'Ehh'. It's just all kind of cheesy. And then you have the characters and enemies, which you just can't take seriously at all. One of the enemies is named 'Crabby Dabby Doo', which makes me feel like I'm getting beaten over the head by a minion. It's a dumb game. But it's also huge and fun and I wasted a ton of hours playing this.

title: Fortnite
description: The Island you once knew has been turned upside down...literally. Step foot onto the new Island and explore every corner of an undiscovered world in Fortnite Chapter 3 Season 1: Flipped. Swing through the iconic Daily Bugle or slide into Sanctuary, homebase of The Foundation and The Seven. Join The Seven as they prepare for a looming war against the Imagined Order across a once-frozen landscape filled with new POIs and dangerous new weather conditions to test your skills. Plus earn XP beyond Battle Royale to level up your Battle Pass and unlock Spider-Man, The Foundation, and all the new Battle Pass cosmetics. See you on the flip side!

myData.review: It's Fortnite, you know what this is. Like Fall Guys, it's free and I had fun the couple times I played it, but I have no interest in going back to it. Maybe I'm not used to modern games that aren't Nintendo or indie, but my god there are a lot of menu screens. And the game being free, it's 99% unavailable. If you don't care about any of that and just go to the main game, it's kind of fun. I got tired of it quick though. I mostly played it out of curiosity of what the big deal was. They must have put me in with all the babies because I kept winning my matches, and I don't think I'm particularly good. Which kind of brings me to my next point - that the silliness of the costumes, and the freeness of the game, skews the whole ecosystem to much younger players. And honestly, I'd rather just let them have this one and stay out of the fort(nite).

title: Animal Well
description: Explore the intricate labyrinth and uncover its many secrets. Hatch from your flower and spelunk through the beautiful and sometimes haunting world of Animal Well, a pixelated wonder rendered in intricate audio and visual detail.

myData.review: Dunkey's own Bigmode Publishing's first release. This is a beautiful, atmospheric game that promotes exploration and problem solving. With its low/no-combat, cavern like aesthetics and old school tube-tv graphic style it captures a certain mood somewhere in between warm and creepy really well. The different animals throughout the world and their graphics and motions are really well done and interesting to see how you can interact with them. It's a fairly short game, and never quite leaves the initial aesthetics & mood the game starts with. But it's a unique & fun play that's one of the best indie games I've played in a long while.

title: Tetris Effect: Connected
description: Tetris Effect: Connected is Tetris® like you've never seen it, or heard it, or felt it before—an incredibly addictive, unique, and breathtakingly gorgeous reinvention of one of the most popular puzzle games of all time, from the people who brought you the award-winning Rez Infinite and legendary puzzle game Lumines. Music, backgrounds, sounds, special effects—everything, down to the Tetris pieces themselves, pulse, dance, shimmer, and explode in perfect sync with how you're playing, making any of the game's 30+ stages and 10+ modes something you'll want to experience over and over again.

myData.review: Tetris Effect is an amazing game. "How? Isn't it just tetris?" you might ask. "Oh you poor naive fool, how I pity thou. How much you have to learn" I would say in return. To which you'd then likely and justifiably slowly retreat into the bushes. For real though, it is a great game. Whoever did the sound design for Tetris Effect deserves a medal. Somehow the pieces falling into place always fit seamlessly with the music, and when you get a tetris, it always seems to happen exactly at the perfect moment in the melody's crescendo. Each level has it's own unique immersive theme. Sometimes you're underwater with the dolphins, sometimes you're in the bowels of some post industrial warehouse, sometimes space, or the jungle. It's a beautiful, atmospheric experience. But it is also just tetris.

title: Underhero
description: Underhero is an RPG-platformer where the chosen hero has failed, and an underling of the evil king reluctantly takes his place as the new hero. Use timing-based combat to defeat enemies as you venture across the land, face off against quirky bosses, and save the Chestnut Kingdom from your own evil boss, Mr Stitches!

myData.review: Maybe Underhero doesn't deserve a 1. But then again, maybe it does. The best parts of the game by far are the first and the last 10%. I like some of the art design, style and overall story. But the problem is there's this whole crummy middle section you gotta get through. It's not very long, but it's also not very fun. The level design was awful. The different areas felt like they were just haphazardly tossed together at the last minute with no sense of flow. And of course it's always extremely disappointing when any game, especially one with such lo-fi graphics, start lagging or frame-dropping on the Switch. It wasn't frequent, but some parts were pretty bad, the mansion area being the worst. So yeah, the game did have some heart, but the execution really just was not there.

title: DOOM (2016)
description: Developed by id Software, the studio that pioneered the first-person shooter genre and created multiplayer Deathmatch, DOOM returns as a brutally fun and challenging modern-day shooter experience. Relentless demons, impossibly destructive guns, and fast, fluid movement provide the foundation for intense, first-person combat – whether you’re obliterating demon hordes through the depths of Hell in the single-player campaign, or competing against your friends in numerous multiplayer modes. There is no taking cover or stopping to regenerate health as you beat back Hell’s raging demon hordes.

myData.review: Oh hell yeah, this game was awesome! It's a fast paced gory slaughter-fest with some challenges thrown in. Music is great, art style is great. The levels are pretty long, so be prepared when you launch into one. It's the perfect game to play late at night where you can turn the lights down low and the music up high and mess some demons up. It took me a couple levels to get used to everything and feel like Doom 2016 was worthy of its namesake. But once I did, I was hooked. Definitely the most fun I've had in a FPS campaign in a long time. And thank you to the devs for keeping the story brief and the cutscenes non-existent. Only downsides I'd say was that it felt a little short, and the collectables were a little cheesy.

title: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt — Complete Edition
description: Winner of over 250 Game of the Year awards, The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt is a story-driven, open world adventure set in a dark fantasy universe. You are Geralt of Rivia, mercenary monster slayer. At your disposal is every tool of the trade: razor-sharp swords, lethal mixtures, stealthy crossbows, and powerful combat magic. Before you stands a war-torn, monster-infested continent you can explore at will. Your current contract? Tracking down the Child of Prophecy, a living weapon that can alter the shape of the world. The Complete Edition contains every piece of downloadable content released for the game, including two massive story expansions: Hearts of Stone & Blood and Wine. It's the perfect opportunity to enter this world for the first time or relive the adventure — on the go! Features -NEW: Cross-play between PC and Nintendo Switch with Cloud Saves. Pick up your adventure through the world of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt exactly where you left off when playing on GOG and Steam — and vice versa! -A gigantic open world to explore. Visit the luxurious and corrupt city of Novigrad, face the frigid cold of the wind-swept Skellige islands, and challenge the dark forces roaming the forlorn, ravaged No Man’s Land. Sail through open seas, dive in search of long lost artifacts or gallop your mount into combat — the world of the Witcher beckons to be explored. -Unparalleled novel-like story spanning over 150 hours of gameplay. With over 100 hours of core and side-quest gameplay and over 50 hours of additional content,…
displayTitle: The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt — Complete Edition

title: Castlevania Advance Collection
description: Join the fight against Evil in the Castlevania Advance Collection, a compilation of timeless action-exploration masterpieces! In addition to the three legendary Castlevania games that were first released on Game Boy™ Advance, this collection also includes Castlevania: Dracula X and some never-before-seen sketches and artwork from the games! All four games are enhanced with newly added modern features such as Rewind, Save/Load and Replay, making this the best way possible to experience these classics or discover them for the first time! This collection also boasts a handy Encyclopedia, a Music Player with all soundtracks and you can even change the ROM Region to play all games in different versions. FEATURED GAMES Castlevania: Circle of the Moon (GBA) - This was the first Castlevania title released on Game Boy Advance! The story follows Nathan Graves, a vampire hunter apprentice who enters Dracula's Castle along with his Master in order to prevent the dreaded return of the Count. Combine action and attribute cards to create over 80 unique spell effects, ranging from fire whips to ice blizzards, with the 'Dual Set-up System'. Castlevania: Harmony of Dissonance (GBA) - This was the second Castlevania title released on Game Boy Advance! Play as Juste Belmont, the grandson of legendary Vampire Hunter Simon Belmont! This title introduced a lot of new features to the franchise, such as 'Boss Rush' mode and the 'Spell Fusion' system that lets players combine Sub-Weapons with Spell Books to cast devastating spells. Castlevania: Aria of Sorrow (GBA) - The third and final Castlevania game on Game…

title: Star of Providence
description: Descend into the facility and seek out power eternal in this shoot em up masterpiece! Descending in the darkness of a long-abandoned facility, a lone ship searches for wealth, power and the scattered pieces of the past. Star of Providence is a top down action shooter with procedurally generated elements. Explore a progression of floors as you make your way into the depths of the facility, encountering increasingly deadly enemies, fantastic weapons, upgrades, choices and revelations as you venture deeper towards a great and calamitous power

title: DREDGE
description: A single-player fishing adventure with a sinister undercurrent. Captain your fishing trawler to explore a collection of remote isles, and their surrounding depths, to see what lies below. Sell your catch to the locals and complete quests to learn more about each area’s troubled past. Outfit your boat with better equipment to trawl deep-sea trenches and navigate to far-off lands but keep an eye on the time. You might not like what finds you in the dark...

title: Pokémon Trading Card Game
description: The greatest Pokémon Trading Card Game players of all time—The Grand Masters—are looking for one player worthy of inheriting the four rare Legendary Pokémon Cards! Build decks with the Auto Deck Machine, hone your skills on the Challenge Machine, and test your ability in the Challenge Hall. Expand your card collection, duel your way through eight Club Masters, and earn the right to challenge the Grand Masters in the Pokémon Dome! Shadowy figures, wise instructors and powerful opponents await you in this trading card game adventure!

title: EarthBound
description: Join Ness, Paula, Jeff and Poo in their quest to fulfill an age-old prophecy to stop the wicked Giygas (and maybe catch a Runaway Five concert along the way) in the fan-favorite Super NES™ classic EarthBound. Then, travel back to 198X for EarthBound Beginnings, a localized version of the original Famicom Mother game.
